Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y0R-W1V1-DXH2-62T6-00000-00China's Growth Stalls; Senate Impeachment Trial Schedule; Stock Markets Hitting New Highs; Senate Passes USMCA; Combat Flip Flops Founded by Veterans2020-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJames Freeman, John Lonski, Troy Gayeski, Jon Hilsenrath, Matthew Griffin,NEWSFinancial011701cb.231China's Growth Stalls; Senate Impeachment Trial Schedule; Stock Markets Hitting New Highs; Senate Passes USMCA; Combat Flip Flops Founded by VeteransMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Donald Lee

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Sworn in. The Senate opening the impeachment trial of President Trump. We are looking at the next steps as tensions rise on Capitol Hill.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

And we've got a big show this morning.

Joining the conversation this morning, Moody's Capital Markets Chief Economist John Lonski is here, Fox Business' Dagen McDowell, and "The Wall Street Journal's" Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman.

Great to see everybody this morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Welcome back.

FREEMAN: Well, so China needed a deal.

BARTIROMO: Yes, China needed a deal for sure.

The market keeps going up and up and up in the U.S. Record-breaking stories.

Once again, the market breaking through unchartered territory once again yesterday. The Dow, the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq ending the trading day in record territory with a powerful 267 point rally on the Dow, up 1 percent yesterday, 29,297 the close on the Dow yesterday. The S&P was up 27 and the Nasdaq up almost 100 points, better than 1 percent, as markets fueled a -- were fueled by the signing of the phase one China trade deal and the Senate passing USMCA, as we told you about yesterday, as growth in the United States remains on an uptrend.

Over in China, it is reaching the lowest point in decades. Chinese economic growth slowing to 6.1 percent last year. We think it's 6.1 percent. That's what they tell us. Economists are blaming the big slowdown on trade pressure and tariffs.

What do you say, John?

JOHN LONSKI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S CAPITAL MARKETS: There you go. I mean this is as expected. China was much more vulnerable to the imposition of tariffs and the trade war than the U.S. economy. It's showing up in the data. China has a very strong incentive to adhere to this phase one agreement as ambitious as it might be.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: One thing I'll point out that we've got a record in the stock market here in the United States. Meantime, the Democrats are trying to remove President Trump from office. We will get to that in a second.

But there are some good numbers coming out of China. The Shanghai shipping index, which is export freight rates, suddenly jumped to the highest level since 2015. And this is a great -- probably a better leading indicator than economic growth.

"The Wall Street Journal" writes also about this. The price of copper is up more than 7 percent in the past two months. Again, in industrial metal used around the globe, another bellwether for global health.

And then all those surveys of purchasing managers in the Eurozone have shown continued weakness. New export orders have been going up in recent weeks. This is global growth. So, again, the market is telling you something about a global economy rebound.

BARTIROMO: Shipping is an incredibly important indicator.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And so is copper. I totally agree.

LONSKI: And that is because of a reduction in trade risks, that's what you're seeing.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Exactly. And -- and --

FREEMAN: Yes, and the same thing --

BARTIROMO: The market is moving. I mean we're seeing shipping across the world. That's -- that's an indicator of what's happening across the world.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think another interesting indicator, you've been reporting this week on bank earnings, and you see within, especially those JP Morgan results, also Citigroup, some of the others, the business customer getting more optimistic, doing more investment deal making. I think that has a lot to do with these trade clouds being lifted. And if we're hoping for that return to really big capital expenditures, businesses making investments in new plant and equipment, I think the table is set for that now with this deal concluded.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and I always like to look at the message of the market. And the message of the market right now is that this impeachment trial is going to be a big flop.

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I think if anybody really believed that President Trump was going to be taken out of office, we would not see Dow 29,000, we would not see money moving into stocks, if there was a real worry that policies were going to change. So I thing you have to look at the message of the market.

Now, anything can happen in the next couple of weeks in the Senate trial, but, of course, we will see about that.

Go ahead, John.

LONSKI: Yes, this is very similar to Clinton's impeachment, late 1998 --

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point.

LONSKI: Where the equity market took off and went through the roof.

MCDOWELL: Except Clinton wasn't --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we were also on the doorstep of a new era with the dot com boom, but yes, that's true.

MCDOWELL: Well, and Clinton wasn't up for re-election, which is another important point. But you've seen -- I -- we keep saying this on this program, but you cannot emphasize this enough, income inequality is shrinking in this country. You've seen a complete reversal in income growth where it's rank and file workers are seeing the greatest wage gains, not the rich. That this is a reversal of what was happened under President Obama.

BARTIROMO: I love it.

BARTIROMO: And it is really astonishing.

Steve Forbes talked about this yesterday, that there's been a sky-rocketing number of Latino businesses being formed. You have income growth in every metropolitan area in this country. Not a single one -- we haven't had that since the early 90's.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a great point.

Meanwhile, Chief Justice John Roberts swearing in members of the Senate yesterday, marking the official beginning of the impeachment trial of President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHIEF JUSTICE JOHN ROBERTS, SUPREME COURT: I attend the Senate in conformity with your notice for the purpose of joining with you for the trial of the president of the United States.

Do you solemnly swear that in all things appertaining to the trail of the impeachment of Donald John Trump, president of the United States, now pending, you will do impartial justice according to the Constitution and laws, so help you God?

SENATORS: I do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Yes, this coming as the Government Accountability Office yesterday determined that the Trump administration violated the law when it withheld aid to Ukraine and the White House slammed those findings.

MCDOWELL: Oh, James, oh the -- the hang ringing, oh, the GAO said it was illegal.

FREEMAN: Yes, illegal.

MCDOWELL: The funds then eventually released. This is literally something that the left was hanging all of their chapeaus on.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Exactly.

MCDOWELL: What, it -- well, you wrote -- I'm teeing it up for you because you got the --

FREEMAN: Thank you. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Best column in the op-ed page today.

FREEMAN: I was just enjoying your commentary for a moment.

But, yes, I've heard some media reports this morning calling GAO independent. It is not independent. This is a group of bureaucrats that works for the Congress. They works for legislators. In this case, a Democratic legislature, Chris Van Hollen in the Senate, asked them to opine, essentially asked them to agree with him that there was a violation of law here.

I've also heard that this is a non-partisan organization. Just for the record, the employees' union at the GAO is the IFPTE. In the 2016 election cycle, they gave 100 percent of their donations, this is their PAC, to Democrats. So, um, let -- let -- let's not --

BARTIROMO: Oh, my God, 100 percent.

FREEMAN: Let's keep in perspective. There's also the point that this is not a ruling from a court. This is an opinion from some staff who work for members of Congress. And I think as the White House has pointed out, it's pretty hard to make the case there's a legal violation when the deadline was September 30th and the funds got released September 12th.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: I -- let me point something out. If this new information, whether it's what Lev Parnas is saying, again, a credible witness, question mark, whether it's this Government Accountability Office report, this goes to the issue of Nancy Pelosi and co and co rushed the impeachment process.

BARTIROMO: Uh-huh.

MCDOWELL: So if you -- rather than waiting and continuing to investigate, subpoena John Bolton, push it through the courts, they rushed it. And here's where we are. That rather than -- she has relinquished control of the impeachment process. They can say they're continuing to investigate all they want, but now the senators and the House brief are due by Saturday, tomorrow, at 5:00 p.m., POTUS brief due by noon on Monday. It commences on Tuesday.

Where we are now is, the Senate's in control. The Senate control by the Republicans. And they can do what they want. And there's a big move to just look at the evidence that's presented to them to half-baked articles of impeachment. The second one, an obstruction of Congress, which is simply the president standing up for the power of his office.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And so that -- that's what's happening. They -- it's proof to the American people that it's purely political and the Democrats rushed it.

BARTIROMO: And I think people see through it and that's why we see the market performance that we're seeing. People understand that this is just a lot of politics.

We have a new member of the trillion dollar club. A little larger, that trillion dollar club. Google, parent company Alphabet, becoming the fourth company to surpass $1 trillion in market value, joining Apple, Amazon, Microsoft. The valuation helping push markets into record territory yesterday.

And so here you have, again, money moving into stocks, into technology, something that would not be happening if you expected that we were going to see taxes go higher, regulation become tighter and trade deals reversed. That is the trifecta of economic policy that this president instituted and has fueled markets.

FREEMAN: But I think it's also a warning for this president and -- and other leaders that given the value of these companies, these efforts to go after big tech, whether in the U.S. or we see it in Europe on the tax side, we see it in lots of countries on the privacy side, this is going to have a big market cost if -- if the world -- the world's governments decide to go after these companies in a big way.

BARTIROMO: What about censoring conservative conversation? What do you want to see happening? I mean shouldn't there be boundaries so that there can't be cheating around an election?

FREEMAN: Well, I think the -- kudos to FaceBook for standing up to the crowd saying you need to start preventing banning editing political advertising. I think that -- that kind of censorship is not what we want.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: I think -- and I also question whether a new regulator in Washington is going to deliver the balance that people may want as well.

MCDOWELL: But it -- but this one -- this trillion dollar number on Google, it puts a bullseye on their back --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: A target on their back in terms of the Democrats. They will get hammered over and over again by Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, assuming they're not fighting with one another.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Uh-huh.

LONSKI: One thing to remember, $1 trillion is about 5 percent of U.S. GDP. If you have $2 trillion companies, that's 10 percent of GDP. That's mindboggling.

BARTIROMO: Wow, that really is --

LONSKI: It is.

BARTIROMO: When you put it that way, John, you're right.

All right, we are just getting started this morning. We've got a lot coming up.

Nancy Pelosi versus FaceBook. The House speaker slamming the social media giant for what she says is misleading the American people.

Then, from combat to company. One veteran-owned company making flip-flops and other footwear for men and women. We've got that story there.

And then historic auction. President John F. Kennedy's belongs on the block today. We have some of those items right here on set. Wait till you see that.

But we'll slip in a short break.

And then former White House Strategist Steve Bannon is here talking all things impeachment to 2020 and a Justice Department investigation into leaks. Yes, they are looking at Jim Comey. We've got that new information. Don't miss that.

Plus, another manager loses his job over the sign steeling scandal. Carlos Beltran is out and hasn't even managed a game. History is made for one team with a female coach.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

New developments in regard to the Iranian missile strike on U.S. personnel in Iraq.

Lauren Simonetti with the details this morning in headlines. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria.

After it was released that 11 U.S. soldiers were evacuated and treated for a concussion-like symptoms following the strike in Iraq, despite earlier claims that there were no casualties, Iran's Ayatollah Khomeini said in his first weekly sermon since 2012 that it had, quote, divine support in delivering a, quote, slap in the face to the United States. The sermon came amid a rash of violent protests related to the downing of a Ukrainian airplane that killed all 176 people on board.

Well, Microsoft is taking on climate change. It's looking to trap all of the carbon dioxide it's ever sent into the atmosphere by the year 2050. All part of Microsoft's goal of becoming carbon negative by 2030. Microsoft plans to invest a billion dollars over the next four years to support company's developing technology to remove or reduce carbon dioxide.

"The New York Mets" part ways with new manager Carlos Beltran months before the kickoff to the 2020 season. All of this coming in the wake of the MLB sign stealing scandals. Beltran was named in the report in the Houston Astros, but he was not disciplined by MLB. The Mets hired him just three months ago. He didn't get to manage a single game. The Mets will not pay his $3 million salary.

And the San Francisco Giants making her-story, get it, after hiring MLB's first female full-time coach. There she is, Alyssa Nakken. She first joined the team as an intern back in 2014. She played softball in college in Sacramento State. No word yet if she will be one of the seven coaches, the team has 13, but only seven are allowed to dress in uniform for the Giants' games, but big achievement for females in MLB. Go Alyssa.

BARTIROMO: All right. Her-story.

SIMONETTI: Her-story.

BARTIROMO: I like it.

Lauren, thank you.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Beltran?

FREEMAN: Oh, I don't know, I'm not a big baseball guy.

I think maybe this is -- let to sort of no such thing as bad publicity. Maybe it keeps the off season more interesting and get young people into baseball again. I don't know. I'm not a --

MCDOWELL: I -- a lot of baseball --

LONSKI: I --

MCDOWELL: Steve Forbes, Brian Kilmeade, they think that this is a huge cheating scandal that will damage baseball and put an asterisk next to the Astros World Series championship.

LONSKI: Then you know all about the 2018 Red Sox, the degree to which they benefited from cheating. You know, Alex Cora was the manager, came from Houston with the same technique, shady techniques that perhaps helped his team.

And then you ask yourself, the money these guys are getting paid on the Red Sox, I think one guy signed a contract for one year for $27 million. He was the MVP in 2018. Were those numbers inflated by cheating.

BARTIROMO: Yes, big numbers.

All right, we'll take a break.

When we come back, not quitting each other. GAP decide to call off its split with Old Navy. More on that and the about face. The stock is, as you can see, up 5.25 percent this morning on that news.

Then singer selected. Demi Lovato's new Super Bowl gig making buzz this morning.

We're back right after this break. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Markets are breaking records again. Check out the futures this morning. We're looking at a gain of about 80 points on the Dow Jones Industrial average, pushing further into uncharted territory. All three major indices closing at the highs of the day yesterday with strong gains across the board. Investors riding high off of the strong bank earnings that we saw this week and the phase one China trade deal signing. That ceremony this week.

Joining us right now to talk more about markets and investing today is Skybridge Capital co-Chief Investment Officer Troy Gayeski.

Troy, it's great to see you.

TROY GAYESKI, CO-CIO, SKYBRIDGE CAPITAL: Yes, great to see you again.

BARTIROMO: So would you put new money to work in stocks now or are you shorting this market?

GAYESKI: No, I think you want to put new money to work until the Feds stops expanding their balance sheet, which they claim they're going to do until the end of Q2, but they've given themselves plenty of wiggle room to continue to expand that.

What we know is that that's -- the Fed's the most powerful institution. They've been driving markets since the financial crisis. They took a pause there in '17 and '18 when fiscal policy took over. But the -- the path of least resistance is higher prices for the time being.

FREEMAN: So is there a multiple that you would say, OK, it's time to stop buying?

GAYESKI: Yes, I think 20x (ph). I mean our thesis coming into the year is - -

FREEMAN: Twenty times forward earnings --

GAYESKI: Forward earnings, yes.

FREEMAN: On the S&P?

GAYESKI: That's correct. Yes. So coming into the year, we were roughly 18, 18.2. And our thesis was that at some point in the first half you had a reasonable probability to hit 20. After that, I think you want to get a little more cautious because remember what the Fed is doing here and, you know, they've done so many policies changes over the last 18 months that you can't discount that.

But basically what they're doing is they're running -- they're willing to run higher probability of medium-term bubble risk in order to further lower near term recession risk. But it -- but once they stop extending their balance sheet, there -- there will be a correction. It's just a question of how severe.

MCDOWELL: IT's that -- it's that --

BARTIROMO: The color will fade.

MCDOWELL: Well, it's that color because the -- an infant mammal's earliest stool contains a -- the green tint from meconium. So the reason that he's green is a little bit icky.

FREEMAN: TMI, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Well, don't -- the audience was curious, why is the dog green.

BARTIROMO: There's going to be a lot of buzz about that today, throughout the day.

All right, still ahead, former White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon is here, joining me next to talk impeachment 2020, the Justice Department investigation into leaks.

And then cuddle up. Star Wars creator George Lucas snuggles with Baby Yoda, next.

urn:contentItem:5T64-K3G1-DYRW-R103-00000-00China shares recover as central bank yuan support lifts investor mood2018-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisBIZChina shares recover as central bank yuan support lifts investor mood Louise Moon

Mainland Chinese stock markets rose on Tuesday after the central bank acted to bolster the yuan currency, giving sentiment a boost amid a series of issues that have left many investors unsettled.

At the close, the Shanghai Composite had risen 1.1 per cent, or 29.85 points, to 2,750.58, bouncing back from Monday's drop to near a 30-month low set in August. The CSI 300 Index of big caps gained 1.3 per cent, or 42.07 points, to 3,363.90, while the ChiNext gauge of smaller companies edged up 0.8 per cent, or 11.81 points, to 1,455.50.

Before the market open, the yuan edged up against the US dollar after the People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.8183 per dollar, 0.24 per cent higher than the previous fix. That triggered a round of bargain hunting in stocks after recent falls, said Francis Lun, chief executive officer of Geo Securities.

He also noted that the improved mood had offset concerns over draft rules by the China Securities Regulatory Commission released on Friday for a trading link between the Shanghai and London stock exchanges. The plan has raised the question of whether money would flow out of Chinese stocks.

"There is a Chinese saying: the thunder is big but the rain is very small - a lot of sound but little substance. It is like the Hong Kong-China connect - not as big as was expected," he said.

Meanwhile, concerns over turbulence in emerging markets would be restricted to Argentina and Turkey with East Asia seeing minimal impact, he said.

In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index gained 0.94 per cent, or 260.80 points, to 27,973.34, but was unable to recover the 28,000 level amid lingering concerns over the ongoing US-China trade war and its impact on the city. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index rose 0.71 per cent, or 77.06 points, to 10,890.63.

Among movers, Tencent rebounded with a 1.74 per cent rise to HK$338.60, in its first gain in five days. The technology giant is one of the key investors in Meituan Dianping, China's largest online services platform, which is planning a US$4.4 billion initial public offering in Hong Kong. It would be the city's second big tech float this year, after mobile phone maker Xiaomi.

CK Asset, one of the flagship companies of the Cheung Kong conglomerate, rose 4.78 per cent to HK$58.15 after it said it had bought back 1.8 million shares for HK$100.2 million (US$12.8 million). Its sister company, CK Hutchison Holdings, gained 3.1 per cent to HK$91.25.

Telecoms gained traction late in the day after Bloomberg reported that the Chinese government may engineer a merger between carriers to boost its push into advanced 5G mobile networks. China Unicom climbed 5.86 per cent to HK$9.58, having reached a 30-day high of HK$9.77 earlier in the session and leading gains on the Hang Seng Index. China Telecom rose 4.01 per cent to HK$3.89.

Mainland Chinese banks were heavily traded throughout the day, seeing slight gains by the close. China Construction Bank ended up 0.58 per cent at HK$6.97, Bank of China rose 0.28 per cent to HK$3.53 and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China ended up 0.35 per cent to HK$5.79.

Insurer Ping An, which saw the second highest turnover, rose 1.25 per cent to HK$76.80.

urn:contentItem:5YBR-KMW1-DXP9-91XW-00000-00China’s high-tech champions get preferential treatment2020-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisChina’s high-tech champions get preferential treatmentJames Kynge and Mercedes Ruehl

FT subscribers can click here to receive Tech Scroll Asia by email.Hi all — James here from Hong Kong. Well, it’s been another week in the g... FT subscribers can click here to receive Tech Scroll Asia by email. Hi all — James here from Hong Kong. Well, it’s been another week in the grip of the...

FT subscribers can click here to receive Tech Scroll Asia by email.Hi all — James here from Hong Kong. Well, it’s been another week in the g... FT subscribers can click here to receive Tech Scroll Asia by email. Hi all — James here from Hong Kong. Well, it’s been another week in the grip of the...

FT subscribers can click here to receive Tech Scroll Asia by email.Hi all — James here from Hong Kong. Well, it’s been another week in the g...

FT subscribers can click here to receive Tech Scroll Asia by email.

Hi all — James here from Hong Kong. Well, it’s been another week in the grip of the rapidly-globalising COVID-19. I’m now spending a good chunk of time explaining to friends and family in Europe how they can expect their daily lives to change as the virus spreads. Is the effective shutdown of the global economy now possible? I don’t get the sense that Europe or the US are well prepared. Our main scoop this week shows how China is carving out special treatment to allow a few high-tech champions to keep manufacturing. Also check out the CSIS’s comprehensive report (When sages speak) on China’s tech advance and Delivery Hero’s appetite for an Asian saga (In the spotlight). Finally, don’t forget Tech Scroll Asia is free for one month — get your friends or colleagues to sign up  here.

The Big Story — Exclusive

Dispatches from China’s virus-hit supply chain present a mixed picture. This  on-the-spot report  from the FT’s Sun Yu in Henan province depicts deep disruption. But semiconductor and display makers in Wuhan, the centre of the outbreak, are being given special permission to maintain operations, according to this exclusive in the Nikkei Asian Review.

The special treatment for Yangtze Memory Technologies — a memory chipmaker that aims to be a rival to Samsung, SK Hynix and others — underlines its strategic importance to Beijing. It is allowed to continue shipping products out of Wuhan and has received components in through the city’s cordon sanitaire since early February, sources said. 

Key implications: Such special treatment is repeated for display industry leaders BOE Technology Group and China Star Optoelectronics Technology, which also have facilities in Wuhan. These companies make screens for smartphones, computers, televisions, tablets and other appliances. 

BOE has also issued “virus bonds”, taking advantage of the newly-sanctioned financial instruments to maintain cash flows throughout its network of affiliates to keep operations going.

Upshot: The willingness of Chinese authorities to make rare special concessions to important tech companies shows the high esteem in which such corporations are held. But the general disruption across China’s supply chain appears set to persist, particularly for small and medium enterprises with lower priority access to resources and official favour.

Mercedes’ top 10

A round-up of the week’s best tech stories from the FT’s Asia tech reporter Mercedes Ruehl.

The head of TikTok’s India business laid out a bullish vision in an interview with our New Delhi reporter Stephanie Findlay, predicting  50 per cent growth  in users in 2020 after being temporarily banned last year. It comes the same week that the app — owned by China’s ByteDance — dethroned WhatsApp as the  world’s most downloaded app. 

China’s largest cyber security vendor has accused the CIA of hacking Chinese companies and government agencies for more than 11 years. The efforts focused on civil aviation, according to  its report. 

Hundreds of billions of dollars were wiped off the combined value of the five biggest US tech stocks owing to coronavirus fears last week. The  FT’s Richard Waters  argues it makes sense that the stocks with the loftiest growth expectations have suffered the most.

Students and teachers in subjects such as obstetrics and gynaecology have found themselves unexpectedly  wrangling with Chinese censorship as they move classes online because of the outbreak. 

Can Samsung withstand the coronavirus crisis? Our reporters in Seoul looked at how the fate of South Korea’s economy  is closely tied to the conglomerate. 

Deliveries of smartphones, headphones and computers in shops are facing huge delays thanks to the breakdown of China-based electronics supply chains. In one example, shipment times for Dell computers to Australia have gone from the usual three to five weeks to 10 weeks.  More here.

On the flip side, e-learning providers are booming. The number of students who have registered with Hong Kong-based education app Snapask in the past two months accounts for nearly a third of the 1.3m new users it accumulated in one year. The  gaming  industry is seeing similar surges.

Here’s more evidence of the seismic shift in SoftBank-backed Oyo’s fortunes. Its Japan unit has suffered a dramatic drop in valuation after its joint venture partner sold its $77m stake  for $3, according to a Nikkei Asian Review scoop.

Europe’s status as a battleground for the tussle between China’s Huawei and the US is growing more pronounced. After being allowed to supply 5G in the UK in January, Huawei now wants to build its first manufacturing  plant in France. 

Mobile dating in south-east Asia is getting the  come-hither treatment from Chinese and US tech companies. Indonesians appear game, spending $5.8m on mobile dating apps last year — a 260 per cent increase on 2017.

When sages speak

Here is an excellent, comprehensive  report edited by Scott Kennedy at the Center for Strategic and International Studies on China’s uneven high-tech drive. You can find informative chapters on many aspects of China’s tech advance from 5G telecoms to semiconductors to artificial intelligence and electric vehicles.

Amit Bhandari and Aashna Agarwal at Gateway House in India look at Chinese corporate investments into Indian tech start-ups in  this interesting report. 

Here is a fine piece by Jeffrey Ding of the ChinAI newsletter that looks at China’s work towards creating artificial intelligence standards and the extraordinary boom in the country’s biometric recognition market, which boasts at least 4,000 companies. 

This podcast about the video conferencing company Zoom is one for the viral times we live in. It was recorded back in 2018 by the folk at GGV Capital, but it nevertheless makes for an interesting story. Eric Yuan, the founder, tells how Zoom was inspired by the unhappy customers of his previous company, Cisco WebEx. 

Heard by Henny

When Alibaba raised almost $13bn in a Hong Kong share listing late last year, nowhere were the sighs of relief more audible than in Tokyo, from the sleek head offices of Japan’s big banks in Marunouchi to those of SoftBank, close to Tokyo Bay. 

Alibaba doesn’t really need the money: the Chinese ecommerce group is performing strongly. But the listing boosted its share price and lifted the value of SoftBank’s 25 per cent stake in Alibaba, which provides the collateral for much of its nearly $140bn in net debt. Alibaba’s stock performance is critical not only to the health of SoftBank and that of many of its portfolio firms, but also to the health of the Japanese group’s lenders — especially Mizuho.

SoftBank has become so deeply enmeshed with Japanese big finance that it is now “too big to fail”. Mizuho, for instance, may have as much as $30bn in total exposure to the fund, analysts said. Mizuho declined to comment. 

Read the story from Henny Sender, the FT’s chief correspondent of international finance,  here. 

Art of the deal

The flow of funds to  start-ups in south-east Asia is slowing as global investors take a harder look at new companies and their prospects for growth.

Investment in start-ups in the region by venture capitalists and others totalled $9.5bn in 2019, down about 30 per cent from the previous year, according to data from DealStreetAsia, a Singaporean financial news site. The data includes investment by private equity funds and corporations.

The number of start-ups raising more than $1bn dropped to two from five last year.

——-

Ebay is looking to  sell its South Korean unit, which includes Gmarket, one of the largest online marketplaces in the country, in a deal that could fetch nearly $5bn, a Seoul-based newspaper has reported.

Oriente, founded by former Skype executive Geoffrey Prentice and former executives at China’s Lufax, has received  $20m in debt financing from Silverhorn Group in Hong Kong. 

In the spotlight

Delivery Hero is ready for an Asian saga. The German company’s planned $4bn acquisition of South Korea’s food delivery app Woowa Brothers, founded by designer Kim Bong Jin, would  spearhead its move not only into Korea but also into south-east Asia. 

The move would bring Woowa into closer combat with Grab and Gojek, purveyors of south-east Asian super apps. Woowa’s margins are under pressure owing to cut-throat competition — one of the reasons it is looking to hook up with Delivery Hero. Delivery costs will only rise further as the company expands into new markets. 

That’s one reason why Mr Kim is expanding its services, for instance  lending out robots  to restaurants. So far, investors have given the plan an approving nod: Delivery Hero’s stock is trading 40 per cent above the level before the Woowa deal was announced in December.

Smart data

China’s already fragile start-up sector has caught the coronavirus chill. The number of venture capital deals in China dropped 64 per cent in January and February compared with January and February last year, while the amount of capital raised fell 66 per cent, according to Preqin data. To make it through the cash crunch, many companies have cut wages and laid off workers. Ryan McMorrow and Nian Liu in Beijing  have more.

Regulation round-up

A stand-off over Pakistan’s digital censorship law ended in favour of big US tech companies including Facebook, Twitter and Google. But the skirmish is a sign of a global trend that has seen big western tech companies tango with national governments in Asia that are seeking to curtail internet content. India is another example, with its proposed data privacy law. Can the unified resistance by Big Tech in Pakistan work again?  This piece in the NYT is worthy of your time.

We always want to hear your thoughts and feedback, so please drop us an email at .

urn:contentItem:60Y2-G581-JBNF-W23P-00000-00China's industrial profits lift markets; Uber wins London licence; pound rallies - as it happened2020-09-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:18China's industrial profits lift markets; Uber wins London licence; pound rallies - as it happenedGraeme Wearden

Rolling coverage of the latest economic and financial newsVictory for UberPound jumps on Brexit deal hopesIntro: Chinese factory revival continuesChina's industrial profits up 19% in AugustFTSE 100 jumps 1%, led by HSBCDiageo: Drinks sales are improving

block-time published-time 5.01pm BST

Afternoon summary

Time for a recap

Stock markets have surged across the globe today after strong data from China lifted hopes for the global economy.

Profits at Chinese industrial companies jumped by 19% in August, the fourth straight month of gains. The figures suggest that China's economy is continuing to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, with demand picking up at home and abroad.

The news sparked a rally in Asia, and helped European stocks to rally by over 2% today - in their best session since June (a day after the worst session since June!).

Wall Street is also higher, with the Dow currently up 492 points or 1.8% at 27,666.

A deputy governor at the Bank of England has indicated that he doesn't believe interest rates should be cut below zero.

Sir Dave Ramsden's comments helped to send the pound sharply higher today, with sterling up 1% against the US dollar, and 0.7% higher against the euro.

The pound also benefitted from hopes of a Brexit deal, with crunch talks between the UK and EU resuming this week.

Related: Confidence in UK's global role plunges after Brexit, poll finds

In other news...

ECB president Christine Lagarde has warned that the eurozone recovery is fragile, so politicians need to provide job retention schemes and loan guarantees

Uber has been granted a further 18-month licence in London after an appeal found it was a "fit and proper" company to run private hire car services.

The owner of Pizza Hut restaurants in the UK is pressing on with plans to shut 29 sites, putting 450 jobs at risk

Caesars, the US gambling firm, says it is in "advanced discussions" concerning a possible cash offer for William Hill

Budget supermarket chain Aldi is creating 4,000 UK jobs...

.. as the race to takeover rival ASDA speeds up

Goodnight. GW

block-time published-time 4.39pm BST

Stocks soar as optimism sweeps markes

Boom! European stock markets have posted very strong gains, as a burst of optimism sends share up across the globe.

The Stoxx 60 0 index of European listed companies has closed 2.3% higher tonight, as it made a strong recovery from last week's losses.

Germany's DAX led the rally, surging 3.2%, with France's CAC gaining over 2.3%.

Every sector gained ground, led by banks and consumer cyclical firms. Hearing aid manufacturer Sonovo surged 13%, and steelmaker ArcelorMittal gained 11%.

In London, the FTSE 100 index ended the day 85 points higher at 5927, a one-week closing high. Banks including HSBC, Natwest and Lloyds were among the risers, on relief that the Bank of England may not impose negative interest rates, along with property firm Land Securities.

Fawad Razaqzada, analyst at ThinkMarkets, reckons investors appear to be warming towards equities and other risk assets again.

After all, ' nothing has fundamentally changed so why not buy everything at slightly discounted prices again after the recent sell-off, ' is a question the bulls will be asking themselves. Central bankers have made it crystal clear that interest rates will remain very low for a long time to come and will be there to provide further support should it be required.

The relatively low COVID-linked deaths mean investors are not showing too much concern towards rising virus cases. Instead, they remain optimistic over the potential approval of a vaccine soon, which together with ongoing central bank support will probably help accelerate the recovery.

What's more, we have had data showing profits at industrial companies in China grew for a fourth consecutive month in August, underscoring economic recovery signs. Sentiment has also been supported, among other things, by hopes that the UK and EU officials will make progress as a key week of Brexit talks begins. This may help explain why the pound was clearly the biggest riser among the major currencies this morning.

Mohsin and Zuber Issa, who are working with the private-equity firm TDR Capital, have pushed out a rival offer from the private-equity firm Apollo Global Management (who are also in the race to buy William Hill...)

block-time published-time 3.32pm BST

Britain's stock market is pushing higher, with bank shares getting a lift from today's burst of optimism.

HSBC is still sharply higher, up 8%, after China's Ping An expanded its stake in the lender. Other financial stocks are rallying too, with Natwest up 7.5%, Lloyds gaining 7% and Barclays up 6.9%.

Sir Dave Ramsden's suggestion that the Bank of England won't cut interest rates below zero is bolstering the banking sector - as negative rates are extremely bad for profitability.

So with an hour to go, the FTSE 100 is now up 106 points or 1.8% at 5949.

block-time published-time 3.02pm BST

Lagarde: Covid-19 threatens economic recovery

The head of the European Central Bank, Christine Lagarde, has warned that the eurozone economy is weak - and needs fiscal support.

Testifying to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament, Lagarde warns that the recovery is highly dependent on the Covid-19 pandemic - so government packages to protect loans and jobs are vital.

Lagarde explains:

The impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic is still being felt across the euro area. Businesses are facing difficulties, people are losing their jobs, and prospects about the future remain uncertain.

While euro area economic activity rebounded in the third quarter, the recovery remains incomplete, uncertain and uneven. Consumer spending has resumed significantly, but consumers remain cautious owing to anxiety about their job and income prospects.

Similarly, business investment has been picking up, but weaker demand and elevated uncertainty continue to weigh on firms' investment plans.

In this context, job retention schemes and national guarantees on bank loans remain critically important factors in reducing uncertainty and softening the impact of the pandemic.

The public health crisis will "continue to weigh on economic activity and poses downside risks to the economic outlook", Lagarde adds.

block-time published-time 2.36pm BST

Wall Street jumps

The New York stock exchange has opened sharply higher, as investors try to put recent losses behind them.

The D ow Jones industrial average has jumped by 376 points, or 1.4%, to 27,550.

The broader S&P 500 is up 48 points or 1.5% at 3,346, while the tech-focused Nasdaq is up 159 points or 1.4% at 11,072.

This follows some choppy weeks - with the Dow falling over 4% during the last four weeks.

The jump in Chinese industrial profits overnight may have lifted the mood on Wall Street. There's also renewed hope that Congress might agree a new package to protect the US economy from the pandemic.

Marios Hadjikyriacos of XM explains:

The recovery in stocks likely comes down to hopes that a US stimulus deal isn't entirely dead after all. The market selloff has evidently put enough pressure on politicians to water down their demands, with the Democrats unveiling a new proposal of $2.4 trillion and keeping the door open for an even smaller package of $2.2 trillion.

block-time published-time 2.30pm BST

While jobs are being created at Aldi, they're unfortunately also being lost at Pizza Hut.

The owner of Pizza Hut restaurants in the UK will go ahead with plans to shut 29 sites, putting 450 jobs at risk, after creditors voted through an agreement to try to save the pandemic-hit business.

Pizza Hut Restaurants, the brand's biggest franchise arm in the UK, has agreed a reduction in rent and bills with its landlords and other creditors through a company voluntary arrangement (CVA).

The CVA will not affect Pizza Hut's delivery operations, which are operated separately. The UK restaurants are run under a franchise arrangement with Yum! Brands, the S&P 500 company that is also the owner of the KFC and the Mexican-themed Taco Bell chains.

The closures will be spread across much of the UK, with branches in London, Glasgow and Cardiff among those affected. However, the deal will save the jobs of more than 5,000 workers, a spokeswoman said.

Related: Pizza Hut confirms 29 UK restaurants to close, putting 450 jobs at risk

Brexit hopes lift pound to three-week high vs euro

Brexit deal optimism has lifted the pound to a three-week high against the euro, up one euro cent at (EURO)1.105.

Some traders are hopeful that the crunch talks between UK and EU negotiators this week could lead to a breakthrough.

The pound vs the euro over the last quarter Photograph: Refinitiv

John Hardy of S axo Bank says there is a "more positive tone" surrounding the negotiations, but points out there are still serious hurdles to overcome:

The Brexit talks are set to get more formal this week and starting tomorrow, with this round seen as a last dash effort if any agreement is to be made on Boris Johnson's timeline aiming for mid-October agreement.

Particular focus from the EU side will apparently be on how any trade deal will be enforced after the recently passed Brexit bill could walk back key portions of the Withdrawal Agreement, which effectively stipulated a customs border across the Irish Sea (separating Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.)

Brad Bechtel of Jefferies is somewhat sceptical, though, telling clients:

There were some positive articles in the press about the prospects for Brexit.

The 9th week of negotiation begins today and there were articles indicating that both sides seem to be getting closer which will allow them to enter the 'tunnel' or final stage of talks for an agreement. I'll believe it when I see it but for now its helping the GBP.

BoE deputy governor Dave Ramsden also warned that Covid-19, Brexit and the presidential US election are all risks to the UK recovery.

Ramsden says the slump in UK growth during the lockdown was not as sharp as the Bank had feared, but it still expects unemployment to jump sharply in the next few months.

He also warned of the danger of labour market 'scarring' - meaning some people will struggle to find work even once the crisis is over.

block-time published-time 11.58am BST

BoE deputy governor cool on negative rates

Back in the markets, the pound is surging even higher.

Sterling is now up 1.7 cents against the US dollar today to $1.29, a new one-week high.

Brexit optimism is one factor. Another is that deputy Bank of England governor Dave Ramsden has dampened suggestions the UK could impose negative interest rates.

Ramsden told the Society of Professional Economists that he didn't believe interest rates could be cut below their current record low, saying:

"For me, I see the effective lower bound still at 0.1 which is where Bank Rate is at present.

Ramsden added, though, that the BoE had a duty to examine whether negative rates could play a role in the recovery.

This is a hot issue at the Bank. Over the weekend, BoE rate setter Silvana Tenreyro said there are "encouraging signs" that negative interest rates could boost the struggling economy.

She told the Sunday Telegraph:

"We have been discussing our toolkit in recent months, including how effective negative rates might be in the current context.

The evidence has been encouraging."

Related: Bank of England rate setter backs negative interest rates

block-time published-time 11.25am BST

Full story: Uber to get London licence as court rules it 'no longer poses a risk'

Here's my colleague Gwyn Topham on Uber's London licence ruling:

Uber has been granted the right to a fresh licence in London after an appeal found it was a "fit and proper" firm to run private hire car services.

Westminster magistrates court ruled in favour of Uber almost a year after Transport for London refused the ride-hailing firm a licence extension over safety concerns.

The deputy chief magistrate Tan Ikram said he had "sufficient confidence that Uber London Ltd no longer poses a risk to public safety ... despite historical failings," after hearing three days of arguments this month.

He said Uber had tightened up review processes to tackle document and insurance fraud and it now "seems to be at the forefront of tackling an industry-wide challenge".

Related: Uber to get London licence as court rules it 'no longer poses a risk'

block-time published-time 10.41am BST

Link to Uber ruling

You can read the Uber ruling online, here.

In it, senior district judge Tanweer Ikram says Uber has taken steps to improve its operations in London and reduce regulatory breaches, so deserves to have its London licence handed back.

He says:

ULL [Uber London Limited] does not have a perfect record but it has been an improving picture. The test as to whether ULL are a 'fit and proper person' does not require perfection. I am satisfied that they are doing what a reasonable business in their sector could be expected to do, perhaps even more.

But he concludes by suggesting that Uber could face certain (undefined) conditions.....

Despite their historical failings, I find them, now, to be a fit and proper person to hold a London PHV operator's licence.

I do, however, wish to hear from the advocates on conditions and on my determination as to the length of a licence.

block-time published-time 10.20am BST

Uber wins London licence back

Taxi app operator Uber is celebrating this morning, after winning back its licence to operate in London.

A judge at Westminster Magistrates court has just decided that Uber should be allowed to keep operate, despite its historic failings including allowing drivers with fake IDs to conduct thousands of journeys.

Reuters has the details:

Uber has won a legal bid to restore its London operating licence, a judge decided on Monday after the city's transport regulator stripped it from the taxi app over safety concerns.

Transport for London refused to grant the Silicon Valley-based company a new licence in 2019 due to what it called a "pattern of failures" and Uber argued it has since assuaged concerns over insurance verification and driver identification.

Uber has still been running in London on a provisional licence.

The pound is adding to its earlier gains, amid hopes that the UK and EU can agree a free trade deal in the coming weeks.

Sterling it now up nearly a cent against the US dollar at $1.283, its highest level in almost a week.

But Neil Wilson of Markets.com warns there could be more bumps before a deal is reached.

Brexit talks resume this week and despite all the noise, both sides want a deal. Whilst the UK threw a spanner in the works with the internal market bill, the real substance of the trade deal is what matters. On that front the EU and UK are about 90% there. The problem is the remaining elements and without these sorted there is no deal.

Nevertheless there is hope that they will enter the 'tunnel': the period of closed, detailed talks that would lead to a deal. If there is white smoke this week then sterling will rally strongly, but I would expect this to drag on for a while longer, for deadlines to be missed and for GBP crosses to remain exposed to negative headline risk.

block-time published-time 9.38am BST

Caesars in 'advanced' takeover talks with William Hill

The race to take over UK betting group William Hill has moved forwards this morning.

Caesars, the US gambling firm, says it is in "advanced discussions" concerning a possible cash offer for William Hill, which runs high street bookmakers shops and online betting services.

Tom Reeg, CEO of Caesars, told the City:

"The opportunity to combine our land based-casinos, sports betting and online gaming in the US is a truly exciting prospect. William Hill's sports betting expertise will complement Caesars' current offering, enabling the combined group to better serve our customers in the fast growing US sports betting and online market.

This follows the news on Friday that Caesars and private equity firm, Apollo Management International were both considering a bid.

That sent William Hill's shares soaring 40% on Friday, hitting 312p for the first time in over two years. Caesars and William Hill are already partners on sports betting in the US, and there's been rising speculation that they could combine their operations in some way.

However... traders may have got over-excited last week. Caesars says today it is considering offering 272p per share. William Hill's shares have now fallen back to that level, a drop of 12% today.

block-time published-time 9.23am BST

Aldi to create 4,000 jobs

Budget supermarket chain Aldi is bucking the trend of rising job losses in the UK, by unveiling plans to create thousands more positions across the country.

My colleague Julia Kollewe explains:

Aldi is to create another 4,000 jobs and open 100 new stores as part of a £1.3bn investment drive in the UK.

The new jobs are on top of 3,000 permanent roles the discount supermarket chain has created this year after grocery sales surged during the coronavirus pandemic, while many other businesses have laid off staff.

The German retailer is targeting 1,200 stores in the UK by 2025. Aldi is Britain's fifth-largest grocer with 894 stores and more than 36,000 staff. It is also upgrading more than 100 existing shops, as well as expanding its warehouses.

Related: Aldi to create 4,000 more UK jobs as sales surge in Covid crisis

The Europe-wide Stoxx 600 index has jumped by 1.5%, after hitting a three-month low on Friday night after its worst week since June.

block-time published-time 8.46am BST

Pound lifted by Brexit deal hopes

Sterling has risen against other major currencies this morning, as a crucial week of Brexit deal talks begins.

The pound has hit its highest level against the euro in over a week, at (EURO)1.1003, and is also up 0.5% against the US dollar at $1.28.

Formal negotiations on the post-Brexit UK-EU trade deal resume tomorrow, with top negotiators Michel Barnier and David Frost meeting on Friday. Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove is heading to Brussels today for talks with EC vice president Maros Sefcovic for talks.

Given the disruption caused by Covid-19, both sides are under pressure to reach an agreement - ideally in time for an EC council meeting in the middle of October (Boris Johnson's imposed deadline).

Most UK businesses have been unable to prepare for restrictions on EU trade, due to the pandemic, and are desperate for a deal that avoids chaos at the UK border.

Related: Firms plead for Brexit deal as coronavirus leaves industry reeling

The prospect of queues of 7,000 lorries snaking across Kent does not appeal to CEOs already trying to cope with the latest rules on Covid-19.

Related: Official post-Brexit report warns of queues of 7,000 lorries in Kent

Mohit Kumar of Jefferies says:

The last scheduled talks between the UK and Europe start this week and if there is to be an agreement by 15 th October, then positive breakthrough should happen before end of the week.

We are hopeful that a last minute deal would be reached, but the negotiations have become complicated following the recent UK Internal Markets bill, which is likely in breach of international law.

Diageo: conditions are improving

Drinks firm Diageo is also rallying, after reporting that its outlook has improved.

Diageo, which make Johnnie Walker and Talisker whisky, Smirnoff vodka, Tanqueray and Gordon's gin and Guinness stout, has seen stronger sales in America, Europe, and China.

CEO Ivan Menezes told the City:

Our US business is performing strongly and ahead of our expectations, reflecting resilient consumer demand and the spirits category continuing to gain share within the total beverage alcohol market. Increased retailer confidence is resulting in some re-stocking in the off-trade channel. The on-trade channel is now open in all states, with some capacity restrictions.

In Europe, off-trade demand remains robust and the on-trade channel has largely re-opened with the easing of lockdown measures in most countries, although the risk of additional restrictions remains where infection rates are worsening. In China, the on-trade channel continues to recover, although larger banqueting occasions are returning more slowly.

Diageo shares have jumped by 5.5% to £26.60, a two-week high.

Britain's FTSE 100 has opened 1.3% higher, gaining 78 points to 5921.

HSBC is the top risers, surging by 10% at the open after C hinese insurance group Ping An increased its stake in the banking giant. HSBC's shares hit a 25-year low last week, amid worries that US-China relations were worsening.

block-time published-time 8.02am BST

Here's Reuters' take on China's factory profits:

China's recovery has been gaining momentum as pent-up demand, government stimulus and surprisingly resilient exports propel a rebound.

Industrial firm profits grew 19.1% year-on-year in August to 612.81 billion yuan ($89.8 billion), the statistics bureau said.

That compares with a 19.6% increase in July and is the fourth straight month of profit growth.

However, industrial firms' profits still face external pressures as rising tensions between Washington and Beijing cloud the global trade outlook.

Raw material manufacturing profits increased by 32.5% in August, up from 14.7% in July, according to Zhu Hong, an official at the statistics bureau. This was driven in part by a rebound in the prices of international commodities such as crude oil and iron ore, he added.

More here: China's industrial profits grow for fourth straight month

Introduction: Chinese industrial profits jump

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business.

There's an autumnal chill in the air this morning, but investors are warming to equities again after an encouraging jump in Chinese factory earnings.

Profits across China's manufacturing companies have grown for the fourth consecutive month, government figures released over the weekend show. In August alone they jumped 19.1% year-on-year, as the world's second-largest economy continued to recover from the shock of the Covid-19 pandemic.

This means that industrial profits so far this year are only 4.4% lower than in January-August 2019 -- quite a recovery, given the turmoil in the global economy.

Raw material producers, equipment makers and electrical manufacturers all posted particularly solid jumps in profits

The figures suggest that China's recovery gained momentum over the summer, as Beijing's stimulus efforts kick in.

This is a welcome sign for the markets, amid fears that Europe's recovery could fizzle out in the next three months as rising Covid-19 cases.

Stephen Innes of AXIcorp explains:

Profits of China's major industrial firms remained on the steady path to recovery in August. Indeed robust earnings in China's colossal production and operations engines provided further evidence of a strong economic comeback.

The data augers well for the China growth story and the outlook for commodity prices.

So, after losing ground last week, European stock markets are set to rebound this morning. The UK's FTSE 100 is expected to gain over 1%, having flirted with a four-month low on Friday.

Sentiment has also been supported, among other things, by hopes that the UK and EU officials will make progress as a key week of Brexit talks begins. This may help explain why the pound was clearly the biggest riser among the major currencies this morning. More takeover news: The billionaire owners of the British petrol forecourts operator EG Group have taken pole position in the £6.5bn race for control of Asda after being named the preferred bidder by the supermarket's US owner. Mohsin and Zuber Issa, who are working with the private-equity firm TDR Capital, have pushed out a rival offer from the private-equity firm Apollo Global Management (who are also in the race to buy William Hill...) More here: Britain's stock market is pushing higher, with bank shares getting a lift from today's burst of optimism. HSBC is still sharply higher, up 8%, after China's Ping An expanded its stake in the lender. Other financial stocks are rallying too, with Natwest up 7.5%, Lloyds gaining 7% and Barclays up 6.9%. Sir Dave Ramsden's suggestion that the Bank of England won't cut interest rates below zero is bolstering the banking sector - as negative rates are extremely bad for profitability. So with an hour to go, the FTSE 100 is now up 106 points or 1.8% at 5949. The head of the European Central Bank, Christine Lagarde, has warned that the eurozone economy is weak - and needs fiscal support. Testifying to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament, Lagarde warns that the recovery is highly dependent on the Covid-19 pandemic - so government packages to protect loans and jobs are vital. Lagarde explains: The impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic is still being felt across the euro area. Businesses are facing difficulties, people are losing their jobs, and prospects about the future remain uncertain. While euro area economic activity rebounded in the third quarter, the recovery remains incomplete, uncertain and uneven. Consumer spending has resumed significantly, but consumers remain cautious owing to anxiety about their job and income prospects. Similarly, business investment has been picking up, but weaker demand and elevated uncertainty continue to weigh on firms' investment plans. In this context, job retention schemes and national guarantees on bank loans remain critically important factors in reducing uncertainty and softening the impact of the pandemic. The public health crisis will "continue to weigh on economic activity and poses downside risks to the economic outlook", Lagarde adds. Shares in Uber have jumped 3% in early trading, to $35.54, after it persuaded a London court to grant it a new licence to operate in the capital. The New York stock exchange has opened sharply higher, as investors try to put recent losses behind them. The Dow Jones industrial average has jumped by 376 points, or 1.4%, to 27,550. The broader S&P 500 is up 48 points or 1.5% at 3,346, while the tech-focused Nasdaq is up 159 points or 1.4% at 11,072. This follows some choppy weeks - with the Dow falling over 4% during the last four weeks. The jump in Chinese industrial profits overnight may have lifted the mood on Wall Street. There's also renewed hope that Congress might agree a new package to protect the US economy from the pandemic. Marios Hadjikyriacos of XM explains: The recovery in stocks likely comes down to hopes that a US stimulus deal isn't entirely dead after all. The market selloff has evidently put enough pressure on politicians to water down their demands, with the Democrats unveiling a new proposal of $2.4 trillion and keeping the door open for an even smaller package of $2.2 trillion. While jobs are being created at Aldi, they're unfortunately also being lost at Pizza Hut. The owner of Pizza Hut restaurants in the UK will go ahead with plans to shut 29 sites, putting 450 jobs at risk, after creditors voted through an agreement to try to save the pandemic-hit business. Pizza Hut Restaurants, the brand's biggest franchise arm in the UK, has agreed a reduction in rent and bills with its landlords and other creditors through a company voluntary arrangement (CVA). The CVA will not affect Pizza Hut's delivery operations, which are operated separately. The UK restaurants are run under a franchise arrangement with Yum! Brands, the S&P 500 company that is also the owner of the KFC and the Mexican-themed Taco Bell chains. The closures will be spread across much of the UK, with branches in London, Glasgow and Cardiff among those affected. However, the deal will save the jobs of more than 5,000 workers, a spokeswoman said. Over in parliament, Boris Johnson's spokesman has told reporters there is still "much to be done" before a trade deal can be agreed with Europe. But while there are still significant gaps, a deal is "still possible", he adds (via Reuters). The pound has slipped back slightly, but is still solidly higher against the US dollar (at $1.286) and the euro ((EURO)1.102). Brexit deal optimism has lifted the pound to a three-week high against the euro, up one euro cent at (EURO)1.105. Some traders are hopeful that the crunch talks between UK and EU negotiators this week could lead to a breakthrough. John Hardy of Saxo Bank says there is a "more positive tone" surrounding the negotiations, but points out there are still serious hurdles to overcome: The Brexit talks are set to get more formal this week and starting tomorrow, with this round seen as a last dash effort if any agreement is to be made on Boris Johnson's timeline aiming for mid-October agreement. Particular focus from the EU side will apparently be on how any trade deal will be enforced after the recently passed Brexit bill could walk back key portions of the Withdrawal Agreement, which effectively stipulated a customs border across the Irish Sea (separating Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.) Brad Bechtel of Jefferies is somewhat sceptical, though, telling clients: There were some positive articles in the press about the prospects for Brexit. The 9th week of negotiation begins today and there were articles indicating that both sides seem to be getting closer which will allow them to enter the 'tunnel' or final stage of talks for an agreement. I'll believe it when I see it but for now its helping the GBP. Wall Street is on track to open strongly in two hours time, following the positive moves in Asia-Pacific markets, and in Europe. Big tech shares are primed to jump - with Apple up 2.4% in pre-market trading and Amazon rising 1.8%. The jump in Chinese factory profits over the weekend is lifting spirits in the markets, and helping investors focus on the recovery from the Covid-19 slump. Tech shares are due a good day. Between then, Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Google and Microsoft have lost roughly $817nn during September, according to Marketwatch, which puts the group on pace for the steepest monthly slump on record. BoE deputy governor Dave Ramsden also warned that Covid-19, Brexit and the presidential US election are all risks to the UK recovery. Ramsden says the slump in UK growth during the lockdown was not as sharp as the Bank had feared, but it still expects unemployment to jump sharply in the next few months. He also warned of the danger of labour market 'scarring' - meaning some people will struggle to find work even once the crisis is over. Back in the markets, the pound is surging even higher. Sterling is now up 1.7 cents against the US dollar today to $1.29, a new one-week high. Brexit optimism is one factor. Another is that deputy Bank of England governor Dave Ramsden has dampened suggestions the UK could impose negative interest rates. Ramsden told the Society of Professional Economists that he didn't believe interest rates could be cut below their current record low, saying: "For me, I see the effective lower bound still at 0.1 which is where Bank Rate is at present. Ramsden added, though, that the BoE had a duty to examine whether negative rates could play a role in the recovery. This is a hot issue at the Bank. Over the weekend, BoE rate setter Silvana Tenreyro said there are "encouraging signs" that negative interest rates could boost the struggling economy. She told the Sunday Telegraph: "We have been discussing our toolkit in recent months, including how effective negative rates might be in the current context. The evidence has been encouraging." Uber's general manager for Northern and Eastern Europe, Jamie Heywood, has welcomed the court ruling, saying: "This decision is a recognition of Uber's commitment to safety and we will continue to work constructively with TfL (Transport for London)." Here's my colleague Gwyn Topham on Uber's London licence ruling: Uber has been granted the right to a fresh licence in London after an appeal found it was a "fit and proper" firm to run private hire car services. Westminster magistrates court ruled in favour of Uber almost a year after Transport for London refused the ride-hailing firm a licence extension over safety concerns. The deputy chief magistrate Tan Ikram said he had "sufficient confidence that Uber London Ltd no longer poses a risk to public safety ... despite historical failings," after hearing three days of arguments this month. He said Uber had tightened up review processes to tackle document and insurance fraud and it now "seems to be at the forefront of tackling an industry-wide challenge". You can read the Uber ruling online, here. In it, senior district judge Tanweer Ikram says Uber has taken steps to improve its operations in London and reduce regulatory breaches, so deserves to have its London licence handed back. He says: ULL [Uber London Limited] does not have a perfect record but it has been an improving picture. The test as to whether ULL are a 'fit and proper person' does not require perfection. I am satisfied that they are doing what a reasonable business in their sector could be expected to do, perhaps even more. But he concludes by suggesting that Uber could face certain (undefined) conditions..... Despite their historical failings, I find them, now, to be a fit and proper person to hold a London PHV operator's licence. I do, however, wish to hear from the advocates on conditions and on my determination as to the length of a licence. Shares in Uber have jumped over 6% in pre-market Wall Street trading, after it won its London licence back: In his ruling, Tan Ikram, deputy senior district judge at the Westminster Magistrates Court, said that "despite their historical failings" Uber was now a "fit and proper" organisation to hold an operator's licence. Taxi app operator Uber is celebrating this morning, after winning back its licence to operate in London. A judge at Westminster Magistrates court has just decided that Uber should be allowed to keep operate, despite its historic failings including allowing drivers with fake IDs to conduct thousands of journeys. Reuters has the details: Uber has won a legal bid to restore its London operating licence, a judge decided on Monday after the city's transport regulator stripped it from the taxi app over safety concerns. Transport for London refused to grant the Silicon Valley-based company a new licence in 2019 due to what it called a "pattern of failures" and Uber argued it has since assuaged concerns over insurance verification and driver identification. Uber has still been running in London on a provisional licence. The pound is adding to its earlier gains, amid hopes that the UK and EU can agree a free trade deal in the coming weeks. Sterling it now up nearly a cent against the US dollar at $1.283, its highest level in almost a week. But Neil Wilson of Markets.com warns there could be more bumps before a deal is reached. Brexit talks resume this week and despite all the noise, both sides want a deal. Whilst the UK threw a spanner in the works with the internal market bill, the real substance of the trade deal is what matters. On that front the EU and UK are about 90% there. The problem is the remaining elements and without these sorted there is no deal. Nevertheless there is hope that they will enter the 'tunnel': the period of closed, detailed talks that would lead to a deal. If there is white smoke this week then sterling will rally strongly, but I would expect this to drag on for a while longer, for deadlines to be missed and for GBP crosses to remain exposed to negative headline risk. The race to take over UK betting group William Hill has moved forwards this morning. Caesars, the US gambling firm, says it is in "advanced discussions" concerning a possible cash offer for William Hill, which runs high street bookmakers shops and online betting services. Tom Reeg, CEO of Caesars, told the City: "The opportunity to combine our land based-casinos, sports betting and online gaming in the US is a truly exciting prospect. William Hill's sports betting expertise will complement Caesars' current offering, enabling the combined group to better serve our customers in the fast growing US sports betting and online market. This follows the news on Friday that Caesars and private equity firm, Apollo Management International were both considering a bid. That sent William Hill's shares soaring 40% on Friday, hitting 312p for the first time in over two years. Caesars and William Hill are already partners on sports betting in the US, and there's been rising speculation that they could combine their operations in some way. However... traders may have got over-excited last week. Caesars says today it is considering offering 272p per share. William Hill's shares have now fallen back to that level, a drop of 12% today. Budget supermarket chain Aldi is bucking the trend of rising job losses in the UK, by unveiling plans to create thousands more positions across the country. My colleague Julia Kollewe explains: Aldi is to create another 4,000 jobs and open 100 new stores as part of a £1.3bn investment drive in the UK. The new jobs are on top of 3,000 permanent roles the discount supermarket chain has created this year after grocery sales surged during the coronavirus pandemic, while many other businesses have laid off staff. The German retailer is targeting 1,200 stores in the UK by 2025. Aldi is Britain's fifth-largest grocer with 894 stores and more than 36,000 staff. It is also upgrading more than 100 existing shops, as well as expanding its warehouses. The jump in Chinese factory profits has helped all the major European markets bounce back this morning. The Europe-wide Stoxx 600 index has jumped by 1.5%, after hitting a three-month low on Friday night after its worst week since June. Sterling has risen against other major currencies this morning, as a crucial week of Brexit deal talks begins. The pound has hit its highest level against the euro in over a week, at (EURO)1.1003, and is also up 0.5% against the US dollar at $1.28. Formal negotiations on the post-Brexit UK-EU trade deal resume tomorrow, with top negotiators Michel Barnier and David Frost meeting on Friday. Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove is heading to Brussels today for talks with EC vice president Maros Sefcovic for talks. Given the disruption caused by Covid-19, both sides are under pressure to reach an agreement - ideally in time for an EC council meeting in the middle of October (Boris Johnson's imposed deadline). Most UK businesses have been unable to prepare for restrictions on EU trade, due to the pandemic, and are desperate for a deal that avoids chaos at the UK border. The prospect of queues of 7,000 lorries snaking across Kent does not appeal to CEOs already trying to cope with the latest rules on Covid-19. Mohit Kumar of Jefferies says: The last scheduled talks between the UK and Europe start this week and if there is to be an agreement by 15th October, then positive breakthrough should happen before end of the week. We are hopeful that a last minute deal would be reached, but the negotiations have become complicated following the recent UK Internal Markets bill, which is likely in breach of international law. Every sector on the FTSE 100 is up this morning, led by financials (+4%), real estate (+1.5), consumer-focused firms (+1.3%) and utilities (+1%). But, at below 6,000 points, the Footsie is still down over 20% this year: Drinks firm Diageo is also rallying, after reporting that its outlook has improved. Diageo, which make Johnnie Walker and Talisker whisky, Smirnoff vodka, Tanqueray and Gordon's gin and Guinness stout, has seen stronger sales in America, Europe, and China. CEO Ivan Menezes told the City: Our US business is performing strongly and ahead of our expectations, reflecting resilient consumer demand and the spirits category continuing to gain share within the total beverage alcohol market. Increased retailer confidence is resulting in some re-stocking in the off-trade channel. The on-trade channel is now open in all states, with some capacity restrictions. In Europe, off-trade demand remains robust and the on-trade channel has largely re-opened with the easing of lockdown measures in most countries, although the risk of additional restrictions remains where infection rates are worsening. In China, the on-trade channel continues to recover, although larger banqueting occasions are returning more slowly. Diageo shares have jumped by 5.5% to £26.60, a two-week high. Britain's FTSE 100 has opened 1.3% higher, gaining 78 points to 5921. HSBC is the top risers, surging by 10% at the open after Chinese insurance group Ping An increased its stake in the banking giant. HSBC's shares hit a 25-year low last week, amid worries that US-China relations were worsening. Other European markets have also opened higher, with Germany's DAX gaining 1.7% and France's CAC up 1.4%. Here's Reuters' take on China's factory profits: China's recovery has been gaining momentum as pent-up demand, government stimulus and surprisingly resilient exports propel a rebound. Industrial firm profits grew 19.1% year-on-year in August to 612.81 billion yuan ($89.8 billion), the statistics bureau said. That compares with a 19.6% increase in July and is the fourth straight month of profit growth. However, industrial firms' profits still face external pressures as rising tensions between Washington and Beijing cloud the global trade outlook. Raw material manufacturing profits increased by 32.5% in August, up from 14.7% in July, according to Zhu Hong, an official at the statistics bureau. This was driven in part by a rebound in the prices of international commodities such as crude oil and iron ore, he added. More here: China's industrial profits grow for fourth straight month This chart shows how China's factory profits have been recovering steadily since cratering at the start of the pandemic. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business. There's an autumnal chill in the air this morning, but investors are warming to equities again after an encouraging jump in Chinese factory earnings. Profits across China's manufacturing companies have grown for the fourth consecutive month, government figures released over the weekend show. In August alone they jumped 19.1% year-on-year, as the world's second-largest economy continued to recover from the shock of the Covid-19 pandemic. This means that industrial profits so far this year are only 4.4% lower than in January-August 2019 -- quite a recovery, given the turmoil in the global economy. Raw material producers, equipment makers and electrical manufacturers all posted particularly solid jumps in profits The figures suggest that China's recovery gained momentum over the summer, as Beijing's stimulus efforts kick in. This is a welcome sign for the markets, amid fears that Europe's recovery could fizzle out in the next three months as rising Covid-19 cases. Stephen Innes of AXIcorp explains: Profits of China's major industrial firms remained on the steady path to recovery in August. Indeed robust earnings in China's colossal production and operations engines provided further evidence of a strong economic comeback. The data augers well for the China growth story and the outlook for commodity prices. So, after losing ground last week, European stock markets are set to rebound this morning. The UK's FTSE 100 is expected to gain over 1%, having flirted with a four-month low on Friday. Asia-Pacific indices have already posted gains, with Japan's Nikkei rising 1%, China's CSI 300 up 0.6% and South Korea's KOSPI rallying 1.3%. Also coming up today Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank, is testifying to MEPs about the eurozone economy today. She may face questions about the strength of the euro, Europe's faltering recovery, and the prospect of another ECB stimulus package soon. The agenda 2.45pm BST: ECB chief Christine Lagarde testifies to the the European Parliament's ECON committee 24333 false false Graeme Wearden A textile factory in Yuli County, China, this month. The pound vs the euro over the last quarter The £/$ exchange rate The top risers and fallers on the FTSE 100, September 28 2020 The FTSE 100 in 2020
