Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X1D-SKC1-JB20-G2M0-00000-00China Trade Fight; Interview with Senator David Perdue (R) Georgia; Juul on the Hot Seat; Focus on Markets; Three New iPhones Rumored to Have Three Rear-Facing Cameras; Proposed California Law Classifies Ride-Share Drivers as Employees, Not Contractors; Yankee Doodle Dandy's Debuted First Food Truck in 2013; Big Papi Back in Boston; Fans Upset about ESPN's MNF Score Graphic2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTKurt Knutsson, Josh Gatewood, Tiana Lowe, Jack Hough, Senator David Perdue (R) Georgia, Eric FreemanNEWSFinancial091002cb.231China Trade Fight; Interview with Senator David Perdue (R) Georgia; Juul on the Hot Seat; Focus on Markets; Three New iPhones Rumored to Have Three Rear-Facing Cameras; Proposed California Law Classifies Ride-Share Drivers as Employees, Not Contractors; Yankee Doodle Dandy's Debuted First Food Truck in 2013; Big Papi Back in Boston; Fans Upset about ESPN's MNF Score GraphicMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Jared Max, Grady Trimble, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday, September 10th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

President Trump is doubling down on the China trade fight. He is now touting how the tariffs are hurting China's economy. Plus the need for a is t touting how the tariffs are hurting China's economy, plus the need for a fair deal for the United States.

I'm speaking with Georgia Senator David Perdue coming up. He was in China last week. He held a meeting with China's Vice Premier Lui He. We'll talk about the farmers as well and the impact there.

Markets are lower. We're now at the lows of the morning. Dow futures down 47 points. S&P futures down 6. Nasdaq futures, lower by 24. This after modest moves yesterday on Wall Street for the major averages. The Dow was up for the fourth session in a row but the S&P and the Nasdaq edging lower slightly yesterday at the close.

Global markets this morning look like this and as you can see it is down across Europe. FT 100's down 19, CAC 40 in Paris down 25, and the Dax index lower by 8 points.

We're going to hear from the ECB on Thursday. We'll hear whether plans for stimulus are in the cards.

In Asia overnight, take a look at the indices there. It was largely a higher opening. Shanghai composite though was in the negative column. The producer price index in China for August fell eight-tenths of a percent year over year. That was the worst contraction since August of 2016.

Meanwhile, the price of pork is soaring. It is up 47 percent year over year due to the swine fever outbreak in China.

Juul is on the hot seat -- the vaping giant called out by the Food and Drug Administration for marketing its products as being safer than cigarettes. Now, more states are looking to curb use of vaping by minors. A lot of issues around that -- safety issues.

Plus, it is Apple's big day. The technology giant set to announce new iPhones today. We're going to take you live to Apple Park, get a look at what to expect, phones coming out.

Plus the fast food wars hit the breakfast table, details on Wendy's big bet on breakfast.

All that coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; commentary writer with the "Washington Examiner" Tiana Lowe is here; and associate editor at Barron's Jack Hough. Great to see everybody this morning.

JACK HOUGH, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, BARRON'S: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TIANA LOWE, COMMENTARY WRITER, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": Thank you.

BARTIROMO: What's on your mind?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Breakfast.

Hash browns -- Maria Bartiromo.

BARTIROMO: I thought you were going to say Brexit because that's also on our minds.

MCDOWELL: No.

(CROSSTALKING)

MCDOWELL: The market, the economy -- I was reading an article that was in the "Wall Street Journal about -- going back to 1928, the S&P has fallen on average only in three months during the year. September proving to be the index's worst month of the year going back to 1928. So there's some concern that will this year be a repeat of what happened last year when you saw the S&P peak in the fall. Then you had that big -- but that was the interest rate related. Not lower interest rate but higher interest rate.

BARTIROMO: September is always a tough month, right. And October. Obviously you've got all the big sell-off in October.

HOUGH: I have no doubt that the market is headed higher from here because the stocks are still such a good deal relative to bonds and everything else. The problem is, when you think about the amount of stimulus -- people who are looking for stimulus right now, think about it, the fed funds rate is less than half its historic average, right.

And the federal government is spending a trillion dollars more than it brings in in revenue. So that's massive stimulus. So here problem is when that next economic downturn comes -- I don't see it in the immediate horizon -- but when it comes, how much are we going to have left to boost the economy?

You know what I mean? How much dry powder are we going to have when the next recession that will hits.

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: Yes, especially right now when you're tired rates where they are right now.

There's not a lot wiggle room there.

BARTIROMO: Right.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Even if you shoot me with stimulus -- we're going to have to get creative.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Unless you're going to go the Germany route.

MCDOWELL: we're going to have to get creative. And they reasons, we talked about this yesterday with the reason that you have such low rates around the globe in terms of those set by central banks is because of if the high debt levels that these nations -- and the United States is falling into this camp, because of these giant -- the giant debts that they accumulate, particularly in the last 10 years or so -- we can't handle higher interest rates and what kind of drag is that on the global economy long-haul?

TIANA LOWE, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": I mean we're creating towards a crisis. Highest debt to GDP since it world two and we're not in any major international conflicts.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's interesting that the markets don't seem to be worried about that. You've got There's $22 trillion in debt. The markets don't worry about it until they worry about it.

MCDOWELL: More and more people are coming up to me on the ground, and these are like hard core country voters asking about us. What about the -- right, where are these the conservatives because you're supposed to be conservative about the debt and the deficit.

BARTIROMO: In fact fiscal discipline in the Republicans.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Exactly.

BARTIROMO On the big tech anti-trust lawsuit. We're going to get into it. What might we see coming out of these lawsuit?

Former deputy national security adviser for President Trump K.T. McFarland is here on foreign policy, along with technology expert the cyber guy, Kurt Knutsson on the major Apple event today. They're going to be unveiling new phones. Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

And our top story this hour is China trade negotiations. President Trump takes aim at China's abusive trade policies, doubling down on his long kept promise to secure a strong deal for the United States.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: China has taken advantage of our country for decades. They steal our intellectual property -- so many other things. So now it's just different. And now it's working the other way and Now it's working the other way and tariffs are a beautiful thing when you know how to use them, they're a beautiful thing.

We're going to be talking next week. We're talking now. They're going to be coming to the United States in two or three weeks and we'll see what happens. But unless we're going to make a good deal or a fair deal for our country to China become let's face it, we cannot go back to a situation, we're giving hundreds of billions of dollars to China becomes standard fare. Not going to happen. We can't do it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It comes as both sides work toward a truce with the next round of face-to-face negotiations likely early next month, early October in dc. My next guest just returned from China where he met with top trade negotiators.

Joining us right now is Georgia Senator, member of the Budget Banking and Armed Services committees, and former Reeboks and Dollar General CEO, David Perdue. Senator -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

SENATOR DAVID PERDUE, (R) GEORGIA: Good morning -- Maria.

We want to talk china with these -- got this unique perspective. Both as a current lawmaker and the former CEO of retail giants that were in China likely to affect they get affected pretty by the tariff fight. You're just back from China -- what have you learned.

PERDUE: Well, Senator Danes and I were over there last week as a part of an ongoing effort to develop a relationship with their national people's congress. We met with their chairman and vice chairman. The next day we met with the trade rep, Liu He as you mentioned.

And so we basically listen on and so we basically sent one message and to oat We This president is very serious and he has bipartisan support in Congress said this president is very serious and has bipartisan support in congress to get a level playing field with China.

Look, the perspective here Maria is that we have a new free trade agreement with South Korea under President Trump. We have Japan now with an agreement in principle. We have a USMCA that if we put it all the floor of the before the House and the Senate today, It would pass in my Opinion.

Then we have Europe in here. So china is really moving I think to develop a more level playing field. But it's the series conversation. And it's to be ongoing for a while, I'm afraid.

MCDOWELL: Senator -- it's Dagen McDowell. How long is a while? because there's an election coming up. Not today, in North Carolina, but I'm talking about next year.

PERDUE: Well, obviously the big picture here is that we've got to get the president into a second term to deal with what you talked about just a minute ago and that's this debt crisis that we have and we have to deal with the entitlement programs and mandatory expenses to do that.

But I think right now what we see is an effort to get China to the table again and they're coming back in a few weeks as you mentioned. I'm hopeful that we'll see some progress.

Look, we have already made a lot of progress with China in terms of equal access. What we have is some difficulties with regard to intellectual property rights, the forced transfer of technology, the cyber war, and the compliance with the WTO.

I mean these are reasonable requests that President Trump is doing. And you know guys, isn't it high time that some United States president stood up to China and said look, we need equal access here and a level playing field.

BARTIROMO: Jack?

HOUGH: Senator, if you had to guess -- I was one of these people who thought for sure we're going to have a resolution before the 2020 election because the President isn't going to want to go into a campaign with this hanging over.

But now it doesn't look like that. If you had to guess, would you say before our after. I mean are we talking years that this could drag on?

PERDUE: Well, I 'll let some clear politicians make a prognostification (ph) about that. But I'll tell you this, from a business perspective, this is a deal that can be done. You've got two sides that are not exactly on the same page yet.

And look, you've got to respect the Chinese. They're the largest developing economy in the world. They see us as the largest developed economy in the world. I worry though about long-term intentions that China has disclosed over the last few years. So there's a real strong difficulties here.

I believe that we could get an agreement in part before next year. Look, our negotiators are finely in tune to this. I think Secretary Mnuchin and Ambassador Lighthizer are joined at the hip in terms of this negotiation. You've said that the Chinese are coming back here in a few weeks.

So I'm still hopeful by the end of this year we could see some noticeable progress that we could disclose publicly.

BARTIROMO: So I mean there's China and then there's USMCA. And, you know, we know that USMCA and the trade with China and -- I'm sorry, the trade with Mexico and Canada is more than a trillion dollars -- $1.1 trillion. China the trading is $500 billion.

So Congress is back in session with a big to do list. Obviously it feels like the Mexico, Canada situation is even more urgent than the China story. Eleven trade groups including the Semiconductor Industry Association and the Internet Association are urging lawmakers to pass President Trump's deal with Mexico and Canada.

It's a top priority for Republicans this fall. It's stalling in the House. Democrats are delaying the vote. What are you going to do?

PERDUE: Maria, you've got it. This is nothing but pure politics. This is a deal that got everything the democrats have wanted for the last decade -- stronger labor requirements, stronger compensation requirements in Mexico.

Mexico's already ratified it. Canada's in the process of doing it right now. I believe personally if we put it on the floor of the House and the Senate it would pass today. Americans want this. $68 billion increase in our GDP, 176,000 potential new jobs -- this is a good deal.

It's much better than NAFTA that we're under today. I can't see anything but pure politics is keeping this from being passed today.

LOWE: Senator, I just have one question. You know, you talk about this president needing to be reelected. Right now, we know that the trade war is obviously hitting China much more than it's hitting average Americans. For the average American it's going to cost them about $400 this year. But what if that does uptick before 2020? What then?

PERDUE: You know, in my state, soybean farmers have been hurt really bad by this tariffs. And they're the strongest supporters of this strategy and here's why. Because everybody sees the long-term reality of a level playing field. If we get a level playing field our exports go up dramatically.

And you know, guys, if you want to continue to grow this economy north of 3 percent, which we have to do to deal with the debt, you've got to grow exports. And that's what this president's trying to do.

Look, we had unlevel playing fields on most of our trade agreements for the last 50 years. Actually, since World War II, because we were trying to help the third world develop.

I lived in Asia. Senator Danes lived in Asia. That's one reason why we're trying to play a small part in helping this dimensional relationship with China. But this is a long-standing issue of our own making.

MCDOWELL: Senator -- really quickly, do the farmers need and will they get another bailout from the federal government? I think there have been two, north of $25 billion total, if my math is right. Do you think that more money is headed their way?

PERDUE: Well, we'll see. I mean, the best thing that could happen to farmers is the commodity prices would rebound. I mean we've got the lowest commodity prices in years and that's really devastating right now not only in the southeast but the Midwest as well as well as California. So we'll see.

I think the President has moved judiciously so far and he stands ready to back our farmers. We know this is a strategic industry. It's over half the GDP in home state of Georgia. So the President's got his eye on that for sure.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Senator -- it's good to see you, sir. Thanks so much.

PERDUE: Thanks, guys.

BARTIROMO: David Perdue joining us there.

Coming up, snuffing out e-cigarettes, the FDA issues a warning as one governor considers drastic measures. His agenda coming up on, as you see, vaping devices.

Then watch out McDonald's and Burger King, Wendy's ready to put breakfast on the table, the menu update after this break.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

E-cigarette maker Juul facing more backlash this morning through the Fed. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: That's right -- Maria. THE Food and Drug administration has put jewel on line notice are claiming that the company has ignored the law, marketing its product as safer than cigarettes. Now, the FDA also says the company targeted children. The company could face fines or other consequences.

Also, New York Governor, Andrew Cuomo says that he wants to ban flavored e- cigarettes in the state. New York would become then the second state to issue that ban, following Michigan, which did so just last week. And a former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg has joined forces with the non- profit. Campaign for tobacco-free kids, putting $160 million into a program seeking to end e-cigarette use among young people.

Well, PG&E offering a plan to settle with wildfire victims. It puts $18 billion on the table right now. The proposal put $80 billion dollars on the table right now. PG&E filed for chapter 11 back in January due to liabilities stemming from California wildfires in 2017 and 2018, including November's camp fire, that was the deadliest and most destructive in state history.

Shares of PG&E down more than 50 percent so far this year. Been a heck of a year for that company.

And then Amazon hosting a huge hiring event next week. They're going to be looking to fill 30,000 full and part-time jobs during the career day in six cities. This is going to be September 17th.

Amazon hosting job fares in Arlington, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Nashville and Seattle. Shares of Amazon, as you can see, in the premarket slightly down, Maria, just about a fraction right now.

And then finally, it is morning, it is breakfast time. How about waking up with Wendy's. The chain's bringing back their breakfast menu. They're going to spend $20 million to add more items to the menu and extend hours at their restaurants.

Some of the new items include a bacon breakfast sandwich, a chicken biscuit and this one, a frosty shake made with coffee. So you get sugar and caffeine all together. Right now, Wendy's offers breakfast at 300 locations. This we should say They cut their full year earnings forecast. That's actually been weighing on the stock, it's actually down almost 9 percent right now.

But maybe bringing the frosty with chocolate included is going to be the ticket. I'll let you know because I'm so going to go get one.

BARTIROMO: Well -- good idea, talk about breakfast when you just cut your guidance and stock is down 9 percent. That's a good strategy for Wendy's. But I do like the breakfast idea.

HOUGH: Take it from a fat guy, if you're starting your guy with a milkshake, you're not trying hard enough. You can make a better effort than that. You know what I mean.

Even I do.

MCDOWELL: But what do you think the frappuccino is? It might not be a milkshake but it's got the calories of a milkshake. People are walking around with the vinti coffee frappuccinos in the morning for breakfast.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LOWE: It's fantastic.

MCDOWELL: Does a body good --

LOWE: -- even though in chain restaurants dining is going down. It's now the fast food work are all the rage. We saw it with chicken sandwiches and now you get to see it with the breakfast wars.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But what's happening with the cutting of the guidance? The stock is down 9 percent right now. I mean is that an indication of the consumer or is that a Wendy's problem?

HOUGH: I think it's gotten very competitive there. I mean look at -- who do you have to know in this town to get a chicken sandwich at Popeye's, by the way. So I think it's a tough environment out there for Wendy's.

BARTIROMO: All right. Quick break and then central bank in focus, futures are down this morning as investors await key decisions from the federal reserve and the European central bank. ECB coming out with news on Thursday. Market impact right after this.

And then Monday night thriller, highlights from the Saints-Texans game, the last secretary heroics, coming up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets this morning are lower. We are awaiting key decisions from central banks, this week and next week.

The federal reserve will meet on September 18th. The European Central bank is coming out with me this Thursday. Investors are waiting to see if a rate cut will happen.

Joining us right now is U.S. Bank's Wealth Management, CIO, Eric Freedman. And Eric -- it's good to have you this morning. thanks so much for joining us.

ERIC FREEDMAN, U.S. BANKS'S WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Maria -- great to see you, as always.

BARTIROMO: First -- what are you expecting on Thursday from the ECB and let's talk the fed, because it's not just the fed, we've got, what, four central banks making decisions this month.

FREEDMAN: There's a lot, absolutely. This week we think the ECB has to commit -- in with the big number -- Maria. They've really been probably boxed into a corner by markets.

Looking around them, they see a lot of central banks, you know, north of 15, 16, who have then policy action the last couple of weeks.

And so the ECB because they have more of a stagnant meeting schedule is a little behind the curve if you will so we think they'll be pretty aggressive with a package that likely will, you know, will catch some waves with investors.

Then with the fed, we think the fed is likely to be more pragmatic, probably 25 basis points and really all eyes will be on the messaging afterwards.

So we do think the fed even though they said it's more of a mid-cycle pause, if you will, or more of a mid-cycle adjustment, I should say. We do think that markets are probably driving more of the Fed's behavior than they're willing to admit.

So those are the two things that we're looking for the next couple of weeks.

HOUGH: Eric -- what are the chances that we see negative yields at some point -- negative yielding 10-year treasury let's say here in the U.S. Obviously not right away

Aren't we headed down that path where these negative yields all around the world pull our yields down that low to prevent capital from pouring in and strengthening the dollar too much?

FREEDMAN: It's really important point of focus for us. We don't think that negative interest rates in the U.S. are likely. In fact, one of the comments that you appropriately made in the last segment was about what we're seeing with debt to GDP ratio.

So we do think that while there is a natural gravitational pull of the rest of the world interest rates pulling the 10-year treasury lower, we do look at the math in terms of the deficit out the next five, 10, 15 years. And that's probably more of a tug northward.

So we think that 1 percent would be the line in the sand, if you will, for now. You know, we're at 1.6 percent right now. There's a lot of room to go. If we were to see negative rates. But we would have to see we think more of a push toward 1, on decent volume which, again, for us is a low probability event. So we don't see negative rates anytime soon. Again, mostly because of the concerns about longer term deficits in the U.S.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. And in terms of allocating capital what does that mean to you? Do you want to buy stocks here.

FREEDOMAN: We do -- Maria. We'd be buyers on a weakness, whether you think we're in those air pocketed news right across the global landscape or out of corporate earnings. And so most of the things you'll hear, like you're hearing this morning are pre-announcements from a negative side.

So we do think that expecting some lighter macroeconomic data that we would be buyers on a weakness here.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Eric -- thanks so much.

FREEDMAN: Thanks so much -- Maria. Take care.

BARTIROMO: Eric Freedman joining us, U.S. Bank.

Coming up, all eyes on Apple this morning. The technology giant unveils new products today including the iPhone 11. We're going to take you live to Apple Park, and get all the news this morning.

Then from down and out to an American success, one entrepreneur turning his love of fried chicken into a thriving business. His story, made in America, coming up.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, September 10th. Your top stories right now, 7:30 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

It is Apple's big day today. The technology giant set to announce new iPhones. We're going to take you live to Apple Park, get a look at what to expect from Apple this morning.

Markets are lower, take a look at Futures, indicating a decline at the start of trading. Although the Dow Industrials has come all the way back, it is now exactly where it closed yesterday at 26,837. It's just fractionally moving.

So we're seeing a major comeback this morning with the markets coming back from the lows after modest moves on Wall Street yesterday. The Dow was up for a fourth session in a row yesterday. While the S&P and the NASDAQ edged lower. Dow Industrials up 35 -- 38 points rather, at the close.

Global markets this morning are mostly lower. Take a look at European indices this morning. While the FT-100 just slipped into positive territory, it's up five points. The CAC Quarante in Paris is down five and the DAX Index in Germany is up 39. So it's very much a mixed story in the Eurozone.

Asian markets this morning mostly higher. In China, the produce -- the producer price index was out for the month of August, it was down eight- tenths of a percent year over year, that's the worst contraction since August of 2016.

Meanwhile, the price of pork is soaring. It is up 47 percent year over year due to the swine fever outbreak in China.

Uber's road ahead, spending $200 million in Chicago, this as ride-share companies head toward a major speed bump in California.

And David Ortiz's big return making his public -- first public appearance since being shot, where else, Fenway Park. Big comeback for him.

Plus, an exciting Monday Night for football, a winning play with just seconds on the clock. Wait until you see this. All the highlights coming up on sports.

But first, our top story this half an hour, Apple's big event today, the company is expected to announce three new iPhones.

Joining us right now is the CyberGuy, Kurt Knutsson, to talk more about Apple. Hi, Kurt.

KURT KNUTSSON, THE CYBERGUY: Hi Maria, good morning to you. Yes, we're right here at Steve Jobs Theater at Apple Park. Behind me, thousands of people, mainly from the media, will pour in there to see a brand-new iPhone. Is this it? No, this is the newest phone to me which is about a year old.

But I asked myself, how would they improve this so it would actually get a consumer to buy a new phone at this point, especially with the price point leading up to near $1,000 and passing it even sometimes.

So what if you could put three cameras on the back, a wide-angle lens, a telephoto lens, and another lens, what would that mean? Well, it could open up a door into augmented reality where Apple makes so much bigger play in that direction. It could be 3D capabilities that go with the phone. All speculated rumors at this point. The names of the phone, three of them, iPhone 11, the -- oops, excuse me. And the 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max expected later today.

There could -- there's a rumor that the entry-level iPhone may come in a variety of colors and in also how would I make this better? I have a scratch on here. Apparently, leading rumor is they have developed the glass on the iPhone to be much more scratch resistant as well as more water-resistant, even though this is waterproof to some degree.

Other improvements inside of this, faster processor, you've got the A13 and then a co-processor which could be the secret sauce here, code name Rose, it works together with the battery and processor allegedly to bring about super long battery life. We could be hearing about that later today as well.

BARTIROMO: All right.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Kurt, it's Dagen. I wanted to ask you about --

KNUTSSON: Hi, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: -- the X -- the 11, because I'm looking at the -- so the 11, the 11 Pro and then the 11 Pro Max, is there really a need to differentiate the phones and get a little bit more granular if you will?

KNUTSSON: You know, I think what you'll see in the Pro Max is the larger format phone and then you'll see the camera set that is going to be the big, big news here.

So Apple's got to do something to get us excited. The cameras are apparently it, along with what I would imagine would be a developer kit that goes along with creating augmented reality. So that it's easier for developers to make things that will get us really engage with the iPhone using those cameras.

Drop it down and notch and you're probably not going to see those cameras that's on there or will you. But that typically is where the money comes in in those advancements.

So you're going to pay more for the more space, the faster processor, the longer battery life, a larger phone and then the chassis on it is likely to be glass and who knows what on the -- on the lower end model.

JACK HOUGH, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, BARRON'S: Hi, Kurt, I want to run a theory by you. You tell me if I'm wrong. Most people get a new phone every -- they used to do it every two years, now they're pushing three years. Now people looking at this upgrade, they're going to say, all right, better camera but my camera's already pretty good. Better screen, but my screen is already pretty good.

The next thing I want to hold out for is whatever 5G is going to mean to the world and this phone won't have it. Therefore, I want to skip the upgrade and wait for the 5G phone a year or so from now. You think that the -- what do you think about theory?

KNUTSSON: That could spell big trouble for Apple. I think you're on to something. So, how profound will that camera set be, how profound will the duration of battery life be? If they really nail it and if you can make a phone where I can just throw it around and it doesn't scratch or smash, maybe that compels me to get into this generation.

But you're right, 5G is not in this chipset but it will be in future phones. You can count on it. Apple's made sure of that. But they're a little late to this game.

But keep in mind also, we're fooled into thinking that 5G is everywhere in America. It's not. It's in the very minute pockets still at this point. So that robust next-generation wireless that we're hoping for is still yet on the infrastructure side, a little bit ways out where you can rely on it just about everywhere.

MCDOWELL: I don't even have cell service between my parents' house and Richmond, Virginia. And that's a two-hour drive. And there's zero cell service.

KNUTSSON: Have I suggested a C.B. radio to you?

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE) As if I don't have one.

BARTIROMO: I was -- I was going to say that. You know, there aren't any 5G phones on the market by the way and I -- and I am being told that the first real 5G situation that we're going to see is enterprise. It's not going to be a consumer product right away. It will be more enterprise buying into 5G, so we'll see. But I mean, AT&T says it's calling it evolving, you know, it's advertised its marketing, it's all evolving, you know, 5G.

KNUTSSON: It's a marketing spin, it's such a spin.

BARTIROMO: It's just marketing, there's no 5G phones on the market.

I've got to ask about the anti-trust probe into some of these companies. The company Google facing an investigation from 50 attorneys general of a potential monopolistic behavior. California and Alabama are now involved, the districts of Colombia and Puerto Rico are.

And the key issue that people are talking about is whether Google abuses its market dominance in online searches and advertising.

And Kurt, didn't we see that in the 2016 election where when you Googled, you know, Hillary Clinton, you've got all these great, great stories about her that she was the best thing since sliced bread when you -- when you Googled Donald Trump, you got he was the most horrible person in the world. I mean, the way that they put their searches when you search for something is being looked at.

KNUTSSON: As well as how they finish the search, if you notice, when they begin to type how it will suggest a search for you that can lead you to a negative path and an outcome or pro or positive path.

And when you see these 50 U.S. states led by Ken Paxton, the attorney general for the state of Texas, he'll be leading this charge. This is an enormous concern for Google and for all tech companies here in Silicon Valley, to see all this unified action from states against Silicon Valley and the idea of the monopolies, I think there's a thought now that Silicon Valley has just gotten a little bit too big for their britches and there's not a lot of room for mom and pops or anybody else to innovate and enter in to the market.

BARTIROMO: Yes, all right, we'll be watching that. Good to see you, Kurt. Thank you so much.

KNUTSSON: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Kurt Knutsson there at the Apple event. We're going to be waiting on what Apple comes out with.

Coming up, I'll be talking with the Arkansas Attorney General Leslie Rutledge about the anti-trust investigation. So stay with us on this Google story and the investigations into anti-trust behavior.

Meanwhile, Uber announcing its latest investment in Chicago along with plans to hire 2,000 new employees over the next three years. It's not all good news today for the ride-sharing giant though. Grady Trimble is live in Chicago with the latest there. Grady, good morning to you.

GRADY TRIMBLE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria. I'll start with the good news, the Chicago office will become Uber's second largest in the country, behind only its headquarters in San Francisco.

Uber already has 1,300 employees here in Chicago and most of them work in freight. Now the company is adding 2,000 more jobs here over the next three years. They'll be focused also on Uber Freight which links shippers with trucking firms.

In a statement, Uber's CEO says it plans to invest $200 million a year here, adding, Chicago is the heart of America's transportation and logistics industry and there's no better place to continue to grow our teams and open our dedicated freight H.Q.

Separately, the bump in the road for Uber, Lyft and other companies that rely on independent contractors, they could take a huge hit this week. California lawmakers are expected to pass a landmark bill that would classify rideshare drivers among other independent contractors as employees. That would mean they'd be entitled to benefits and a minimum hourly wage. Democrats including some of the presidential candidates support this move, saying it protects workers. Many drivers are rallying behind it too. But the rideshare companies say that this could cost them big money, up to 20 to 30 percent increase in their costs.

California's governor, he's already said he plans to sign this if it passes, which looks increasingly likely. And there's a wide-ranging impacts for this because other states will likely follow suit if California passes this bill.

Uber and Lyft stock as you see have slumped in recent weeks, partly on news of this. And as you see, ridesharing companies are diversifying, going into other industries like freight. Part of the reason for that is government regulation, as well as the fact that they are still not profitable. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Grady. Grady Trimble for us.

Coming up, an emotional night in Boston, David Ortiz throwing out the first pitch at Fenway, his first public appearance since being shot. Big Papi's heartfelt return.

Plus, made in America, our next guest turned his love of chicken into a deep-fried success story. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. It is called New York City's only all American food truck. That is Yankee Doodle Dandy's, becoming one of the most popular food trucks in Manhattan, due to the patriotic theme and delicious food.

Joining me right now is the founder and CEO of Yankee Doodle Dandy, here's Josh Gatewood. Josh, great to have you. Thank you so much for being here.

JOSH GATEWOOD, FOUNDER AND CEO, YANKEE DOODLE DANDY'S: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Well, here we are in the rain. This truck is gorgeous and I see you a lot. Well, (INAUDIBLE) when you have rain like this, does that cut into business?

GATEWOOD: The rain kills the food truck, yes. So you're capturing what's wrong with the food truck business actually.

BARTIROMO: Oh, God. But you have an incredible story, tell us your story.

GATEWOOD: So, yes. So I've set out on this journey and I was short on capital. I was working at a boiler room on 14 Wall Street right across the street from the New York Stock Exchange and I was broke. But I was studying for my series 763 and was short on capital. But when I was in the -- in the room studying for my series 763 I was like what can I do other than this? Because you know, it's -- the boiler room thing is done now.

So I came up with the idea of Yankee Doodle Dandy's. My directress ancestor was in the revolutionary war. So Yankee Doodle Dandy's was like - - Yankee Doodle Dandy's was our first national anthem. So I wanted to capture like all American food, culture, and that's what I did, so --

BARTIROMO: Wait a second. Go back for a second because you actually -- you won money on "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?"

GATEWOOD: Right. So I was -- so yes, I was short on capital and my solution to my capital shortage was applying for "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?" what any rational person would do.

BARTIROMO: That is amazing.

GATEWOOD: And I kept trying, I didn't get on. I kept trying, I didn't get on. And I would sit there on the 7 train going back to Queens, and like, men, I just want anything to change my life.

So I went back to Knoxville, Tennessee where I went to college and I moved in with my little sister. And I was sitting on an air mattress in her house, and I got the call, right after I left New York. They're like Josh, you're on the show on Thursday.

BARTIROMO: Wow, that's amazing.

GATEWOOD: And I was like, no way. I started tearing up. I couldn't believe it.

BARTIROMO: So you go on "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?" How much did you win?

GATEWOOD: So I got on the show and I was super nervous when I started but it went pretty well. And I got to the $100,000 question and so I had about $40,000 in my like, savings account or whatever and I went for it and I actually flipped the can of chewing tobacco to see if I can win a $100,000. I said if I could win, I'm going to (INAUDIBLE) in the gas. I guess I got it wrong because I got $25,000.

But on the show, I said I was going to start restaurants in New York City. And so it's been my dream and I've been working toward that tirelessly. I didn't win enough for a restaurant. I got a food truck.

BARTIROMO: All right, so you had the $25,000 to start the food truck. What were the big costs involved in starting up this food truck? I love the food truck business. I think it's just the most entrepreneurial business and it's just so interesting that it's thriving in America.

GATEWOOD: Absolutely, it's near and dear to me because you know, it's been -- it was a second opportunity for me, a fresh start. And so there's a lot of turnover in this business because the city makes it very difficult to be successful. We get bopped with parking tickets every day, twice a day. My truck on 46th street is fined with $115 ticket right now.

BARTIROMO: You're constantly getting parking tickets.

GATEWOOD: Constantly.

BARTIROMO: Why you can't find the spot to bear you just don't --

GATEWOOD: No, just -- so the city made it illegal to sell for metered parking. And so you get hit with $65.00 every day. And yes, so they add up.

BARTIROMO: Wow. All right, so what were the big costs away from the parking tickets?

GATEWOOD: Just buying the truck, really.

BARTIROMO: Buying the truck, that was the big cost.

GATEWOOD: But there's a lot of turnovers, you can buy a used truck. I built trucks, you know, there's a lot of different ways to get started so - -

BARTIROMO: Wow, what a long way from the boiler room.

GATEWOOD: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Working in a boiler room. OK, so tell me about the menu, how you came up with the ideas, how the food is.

GATEWOOD: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: I mean, it's not just that you had to raise money to get the truck to start a business. Then you've got to deliver and then you've got to actually execute.

GATEWOOD: Right, so when I went to college down south, being a northern -- I grew up in the north and I saw these chicken places down there and they were absolutely killing it and I had no idea why or how. So that's what kind of where the idea came from.

So I actually went down there, learned how to cook and then came back up, bought the truck, put it in a food truck and it's -- and it's been going.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

GATEWOOD: Chicken tenders have a broad appeal. Everyone likes them. And yes, so --

BARTIROMO: Have you always been a cook?

GATEWOOD: No, I've just always been a business-minded person.

BARTIROMO: But you're cooking now.

GATEWOOD: Yes, and I love it. I mean, honestly, I love what I do. It's just I wish it was a little bit less stressful but --

BARTIROMO: What's the -- what's the big stress involved?

GATEWOOD: What isn't stress, managing people, finding good workers, the parking situation. I've been in fistfights for parking in New York City.

BARTIROMO: So tell me about the growth story then. How many people work for you, how many trucks do you hope to get?

GATEWOOD: Well so, I basically have three trucks right now and I'm tapping out of trucks. I actually was -- so like I said, it was my dream to get a restaurant. I was actually just given my first lease for a restaurant so the dream is coming true.

BARTIROMO: Oh my God.

GATEWOOD: Yes, so I've got a restaurant location picked out. and yes, I made it happen. But America, I'm hoping for investment, if you want to make some money, some all American food, promote American food, I'm your guy.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. I mean, you are the quaint essential American dream story.

GATEWOOD: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Are you living your American dream?

GATEWOOD: Absolutely. And I got people with me, you know, I live with a couple from Morocco who came here, my buddy just got citizenship. He's worked with me. He's stuck -- when we first started I wasn't making any money. He didn't even take pay. Because he saw our food, saw how good it was, and he stuck with me.

And honestly, a lot of people would have thrown in the -- thrown in the towel. But the secret to life, truthfully, is just not giving up. I'm not the smartest guy in the world but I'll out-work anyone. If you just believe in it and go after it and don't stop, you'll get what you want.

BARTIROMO: I totally agree, the hard work is the secret to everything.

GATEWOOD: It's the secret, honestly.

BARTIROMO: People just underestimate the power of hard work.

GATEWOOD: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right, so the food truck industry is just soaring right now. Any thoughts on that in terms of, you know, getting a foothold in an area or an industry that's growing so much and you've got a ton of food trucks just on this street.

GATEWOOD: Yes, definitely. So I'm actually the president of the New York City Food Truck Association as well and I help people constantly. So people call me and say how do I start a food truck and I'm more than willing to just help them out. Because when I was going through it, nobody helped me.

So it's nice to have someone they can ask questions, they bounce questions off me. You know, I don't know everything but I learned a lot of things and I'm still learning every day.

BARTIROMO: Secret to the best chicken tenders?

GATEWOOD: The marinade, getting good quality chicken, keeping it fresh, it's fresh, never frozen, antibiotic hormone-free. Hand breading it on the truck, keeping it crispy.

BARTIROMO: There you go. Josh, I can see why you're successful.

GATEWOOD: I try really hard.

BARTIROMO: Keep on rocking. Thank you so much.

GATEWOOD: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations to you.

GATEWOOD: Thank you, ma'am.

BARTIROMO: Josh Gatewood there. A Yankee Doodle Dandy. Great story there.

We're going to take a short break. When we come back, Monday Night thriller, highlights from the dramatic Saints-Texans matchup last night. All the heroics when we come right back.

urn:contentItem:5X41-7T51-DXH2-64SM-00000-00China Trade Team Cancels Visit to Montana Farm Next Week; President Trump Heads to U.N. General Assembly; UAW Strike In Second Week; Futures Fall On Disappointing PMI Data Out of Germany, France; Recession Fears; President Trump Calls For Probe Of Former Vice President Biden Amid Ukraine Call Scrutiny; Zuckerberg Meets Trump At White House; NY Fed Conducts Overnight Repo Operations For 5th Day; Washington Lifts Tariffs On More Than 400 Chinese Imports2019-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTRyan Payne, Stephanie Grisham, Doug Collins, Katie NixonNEWSFinancial092303cb.231China Trade Team Cancels Visit to Montana Farm Next Week; President Trump Heads to U.N. General Assembly; UAW Strike In Second Week; Futures Fall On Disappointing PMI Data Out of Germany, France; Recession Fears; President Trump Calls For Probe Of Former Vice President Biden Amid Ukraine Call Scrutiny; Zuckerberg Meets Trump At White House; NY Fed Conducts Overnight Repo Operations For 5th Day; Washington Lifts Tariffs On More Than 400 Chinese ImportsMaria Bartiromo, Liz Peek, James Freeman, Blake Burman, Jackie DeAngelis, Kristina Partsinevelos, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, September 23rd. Your top stories, right now, 8:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Futures are off of the lows this morning, take a look at markets, Dow Industrials down 33 points, the S&P down three quarters of one point and the NASDAQ is up 7-1/2, pretty much keeping where we were over the last hour or so.

Last week, the market posted the losing week, but all these three major indices are just within striking distance of hitting all-time highs, even though last week, the Dow was down better than one percent.

Global markets this morning, look like this, European indices are lower. We had signs of a slowdown in the European economy, once again, manufacturing sentiment in the Eurozone down in September, to the worst level nearly seven years.

The Purchasing Managers' Indexes were out this morning in Germany and France. They, too, came in below analysts' expectations. The FT 100 is down 31, the CAC Quarante is down 61, the DAX Index in Germany is lower by 138.

In Asia overnight, markets finished mixed, as you see, Japan was closed for a national holiday, worst performer was China. Shanghai composite down about one percent.

Investigating Facebook, Dow Jones is reporting that Snap, Snap kept a dossier called Project Voldemort on the ways that Facebook allegedly tried to thwart competition. Now, Snap is talking to the government about it.

The General Motors strike is entering day eight. Report say that important progress has been made, but we could still be far from seeing workers back on the assembly line. We're going to take you live to Detroit, coming up. Plus, living rent-free, how's that? A look at why millennials think their parents should let them live at home for nothing, for as long as they need to.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning, and joining me to break it all down, Payne Capital Management president, Ryan Payne is here, FOX News contributor and Columnist for The Hill, Liz Peek, and the Wall Street Journal's assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman. Great to see everybody today.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be here. Enjoyed your Giuliani interview. I think he's got a dossier on Hunter Biden, and this is going to be a tough story for Joe Biden to explain.

BARTIROMO: I thought it was interesting that he said, look, unless this happened, the Democrats and the -- and the media were not going to focus on what Hunter Biden's doing, and now they have to focus on what he has done.

PEEK: I think he's totally right. The story has been out there. It's not a secret that Joe -- but no one's ever paid any attention to it.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

PEEK: Let's not forget, as U.N. week, President Trump's coming to the U.N., always shakes things up a little bit, that's my focus this week.

BARTIROMO: I'm looking forward.

PEEK: Me too.

RYAN PAYNE, PRESIDENT, PAYNE CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: And let's not forget about the trade deal, can't forget that's still happening, they're still trying to negotiate, if that happens, just going to be being fantastic.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Liu He -- they're looking on October 10th, early October for these major talks that are going to happen after the minister's meetings last week. We'll see about that. There were some signs of maybe the two sides getting together, but we'll see. These are big ticket items like intellectual property theft. We're going to talk about all of the above, coming up.

Our top story this hour, questions swirling around President Trump's July phone call with the president of the Ukraine. This, as the president has a packed schedule at the U.N. general assembly. Blake Burman is at the White House this morning, with more. Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you, as well. Three full days of meetings ahead for President Trump in New York City as he heads to the United Nations for the general assembly there.

And no doubt about it, hovering over all of this, especially leading into it, is the story involving the conversation that President Trump had with the newly elected leader of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, earlier this summer. The president acknowledging over the weekend that when the two spoke, they talked about Joe Biden.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We has a great conversation. The conversation I had was largely congratulatory, was largely corruption, all of the corruption taking place. It was largely the fact that we don't want our people like Vice President Biden and his son, creating to the corruption already in the Ukraine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now, Democrats say that amounts to asking a foreign power to dig up potential dirt on a domestic political opponent. In a statement, Nancy Pelosi is urging the director of national intelligence to provide the whistleblower complaint regarding the call to Congress.

Writing to her colleagues over the weekend, "If the president has done what has been alleged, then he is stepping into a dangerous minefield with serious repercussions for his administration and our democracy."

But the president's personal attorney this morning, Rudy Giuliani, is accusing the former vice president of helping get rid of a corruption prosecutor that was zeroing in on a Ukrainian company with ties to Biden's son, Hunter. Giuliani also argues that President Trump did nothing wrong on that phone call with Zelensky.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUDY GIULIANI, PERSONAL ATTORNEY OF DONALD TRUMP: Now, there is no quid pro quo, no money -- proper action by a president, they might say improper. But, certainly, not grounds for impeachment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: At the U.N. for the president later today, six meetings, including with the leaders of Pakistan, Egypt and South Korea. On a schedule tomorrow, the heads of the U.K., India and Iraq, and Maria, on Wednesday, President Trump will also have a bilateral meeting with Volodymyr Zelensky. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right. Well, that's going to be something to watch. We'll be talking about that for sure, Blake, thanks so much. Blake Burman at the White House.

And joining me right now for reaction is the White House press secretary, director of communications for President Trump, as well as First Lady Melania Trump, Stephanie Grisham.

Stephanie, it's great to see you.

STEPHANIE GRISHAM, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY, DIRECTOR OF COMMUNICATIONS FOR THE FIRST LADY: Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: And this is one of the first times you're coming out and having the world see who's behind all of this.

GRISHAM: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You've been in this new roll since June, where you're helping not just the first lady, but also President Trump.

GRISHAM: Correct.

BARTIROMO: How are you dealing with all these -- these are three different jobs.

GRISHAM: Well, women can do it all, so there's that.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

I always say, you want to get something done, give it to a busy woman.

GRISHAM: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: She'll throw another ball in the air.

GRISHAM: Exactly. A lot of multitasking and I have a really, really good team, too, so -- on both sides of the House, East and West Wing both. So they are very supportive.

BARTIROMO: You have been able to really get to know our first lady, Mrs. Trump. Tell us about her because you don't see her around anywhere, you don't see her in fashion magazines, even though she looks absolutely gorgeous, and she's all the time or even talking about her Be Best campaign. Tell us about Mrs. Trump.

GRISHAM: She is wonderful. And this country is very, very lucky to have her as the first lady.

She -- it's funny you talk about the magazines. That's not something that she seeks. She wants to go in, get her work done, work on behalf of this country, and she doesn't need the credit for it. She's fantastic.

BARTIROMO: She's -- she's going to be involved in the U.N. meetings, as well as going down to Wall Street.

GRISHAM: So today she's going to go to the New York Stock Exchange with a local school, with some children. The kids are going to get a tour and kind of learn about this great economy under President Trump, and then they're going to ring the bell, which is obviously an iconic thing to do here in New York City. So that will be really fun. It's part of her Be Best initiative.

Then she'll attend the speech tomorrow with the president, of course, and then they've got a diplomatic reception.

BARTIROMO: Tell me about to Be Best initiative, because I see her with children all the time and she goes and she spends time at these schools. What are the -- what is she trying to do? Tell us her priorities in Be Best.

GRISHAM: Absolutely. So she's got three pillars. She knows that -- I mean and it's -- in 2019 there's no one issue that kids are facing. So opioid abuse is obviously a big deal for her. And then social media online safety is very important. And then just overall well-being. So any kind of healthy living, teaching children to make, you know, good choices, including vaping. She just came out talking about how that shouldn't be marketed to children.

So children are the priority and then just the many -- the many issues that they're facing.

BARTIROMO: I feel like that was a big priority for her, and she basically educated the president on it when it comes to vaping.

GRISHAM: Absolutely. She -- she had a very big role in that. Obviously, she's a parent herself. And it's just very, very important to her that kids understand the dangers of the addictive nature of e-cigs.

BARTIROMO: So we saw what Sarah Sanders, the pressure that she was under. She would take the podium and just sort of try to, you know, take shots from everybody. Are you feeling that you're getting that same pushback from the media against this president? What -- tell me what you're feeling so far.

GRISHAM: Well -- well, I think, just to be honest with you, it's disappointing the way the media has been -- is and has become and the way they treat this president and this first lady.

In terms of the briefings, I don't feel a pressure to be there. The president is his own best spokesperson. He goes out. He's the most accessible president in history. The briefings, to me, became a lot of theater, and it became a way for a certain reporter to just get more face time or book deals or contributor contracts. And I don't feel the need to help them do that.

My job is to talk about what he's doing and communicate his policies and I can do that in an array of ways, what that's what we're doing and it's just working out fine.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about the president's priorities. I mean, obviously, the president is on the world stage this week. He's giving a religious freedom speech at the United Nations today, ahead of the speech to the General Assembly tomorrow.

What are the president's goals this week, and what's most important to the president in terms of his policy priorities?

GRISHAM: Well, I think for this week at UNGA, diplomacy is important. He's going to be speaking with world leaders, allies, and not so friendly world leaders. And so he -- he's going to want to talk to him about our priorities and what we're doing and the ways that we can best work together, but always with America first at the forefront.

The speech tomorrow is going to be really great. It's going to be talking about his -- his priorities and his policies and the things he's been doing for the United States and how he wants to continue to work with our allies to further the American people's agenda.

BARTIROMO: He talks a lot about the economic agenda and certainly moving the needle on economic growth, and yet his moves on foreign policy are also quite significant. In terms of his priorities, where do you see the ramp-up going into 2020?

GRISHAM: Well, I'll tell you, since taking the job I've been really fortunate to sit in on a lot of these meetings. And just at the G-7 in France, he and Japan forged a deal in principle that looks like we'll be -- we'll be signing something in the next couple of days and -- over agriculture and produce. So the president works so well with all of these foreign leaders, our allies certainly. But I think the thing that has struck me is, when he works with leaders such as Kim Jong-un, or Putin that he gets, you know, maybe criticized for being too friendly.

I've seen him behind closed doors and all the president cares about is this country and he works very, very hard for this country with -- with those foreign leaders.

BARTIROMO: Well, he's changed the conversation on China.

GRISHAM: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That's for sure.

GRISHAM: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: And then there's the tensions with Iran, which people want to know, where is this going? The Iranian president, Rouhani, is now slamming latest round of U.S. sanctions on the rogue regime. He says it's desperate. This morning Iran also freed a British tanker it seized back in July, ending a month long standoff with the U.K. ahead of the U.N. summit.

In terms of Iran, do you feel like the president -- you know, going to the U.N., having to see the Iranian president and then, you know, North Korea, I mean how is he feeling going into all of these meetings where they're all going to be right there and he's going to be front and center at that podium.

GRISHAM: He's fearless. He is focused on our country. He will work with anybody. He knows that he's got an obligation to try to work with anybody. But he's fearless and he puts this country first that that's all that matters.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Now, the first lady, she has been right there, his partner, throughout this, even though he's had so many skeptics in the press. Does that -- is that a big issue for her? What does she say about all of this?

GRISHAM: You know, I've learned so much from her. She -- she's -- she's his rock. She really is a rock. And -- and for the whole family. And none of it bothers her. She always say to me, Stephanie, it's all just noise. And it really is. And I've learned a lot from her in that regard. She sees every day the media, she sees how dishonest they are. I mean when it comes to her, when it comes to him, when it comes to the family. So it doesn't bother her and she's very unwavering in that.

BARTIROMO: It's got to be tough.

How are you feeling going into 2020 when you've got all of these people onstage and the Democrats' side trying to take down this president going into 2020?

GRISHAM: Nobody's going to take down this president. He's going to win and that's just going to be how it is.

BARTIROMO: Stephanie, we'll be watching you. Thanks so much for joining us.

GRISHAM: Thank you very, very much.

BARTIROMO: Appreciate it. Stephanie Grisham here on set.

Coming up, the UAW strike against General Motors, entering week two, 49,000 G.M. workers protesting at 30 plants around the country. We're going to take you live to Detroit, get the very latest there.

And then, pay up millennials, arguing that they are entitled to free rent with mom and dad post-graduation, we're going to talk to current students and get their take on this heated debate. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The strike against General Motors now entering a second week. Grady Trimble is live in Detroit this morning with the very latest. Grady, g morning to you.

GRADY TRIMBLE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Good morning, Maria. We're told some progress was made over the weekend, but it's unclear how much closer the two sides are to a deal. Meanwhile, this strike became markedly more political over the weekend. Senator Elizabeth Warren, one of the 2020 hopefuls who paid these workers a visit here at the Detroit Hamtramck assembly plant. One of the things we've been hearing from workers is how they want a bigger cut of G.M.'s profits. That's something that Senator touched on as well.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: G.M. makes billions of dollars in profits last year and closed five plants around this country. G.M. is demonstrating that it has no loyalty to the workers of America or to the people of America. Their only loyalty is to their own bottom line. And if they can save a nickel by moving your job to Mexico, or to Asia, or anywhere else on this planet, they will do it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TRIMBLE: The Senator is correct in that. G.M. posted profits of almost $12 billion in 2018. She also brought up Mexico, and G.M. will point out that it has way more employees here in the United States than it does in Mexico. And it also invests a lot more money here. Meanwhile, while Senator Warren was here, Vice President or former Vice President Joe Biden, visited strikers in Kansas City. Here's some of what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Look what happened when we vote bailed out G.M. We didn't bail out G.M., UAW (INAUDIBLE) G.M. When I say that that's just not hyperbole, that's a fact. You gave up more than anybody. You gave up more than anybody. That's why G.M. made it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TRIMBLE: We're told Senator Bernie Sanders will be here Wednesday of this week if the strike continues. It's clear these candidates are showing their support for the workers, but they also see the value in having the support of the workers come 2020. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Hi, Grady. Thank you. We'll be watching. Grady Trimble in Detroit. Coming up, global growth fear, stocks slipping this morning on trade uncertainty disappointing manufacturing data out of Europe. As more Americans label the U.S. economy as poor and feel it's getting worse. We're going to take a look at that. Then big tech crackdown. Mark Zuckerberg faces tough scrutiny from lawmakers on internet regulation. I'll speak with Georgia Congressman Doug Collins who met with Facebook chiefs on Capitol Hill on Friday.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Futures a little change this morning. We are expecting a decline at the start of trading for the Dow Industrials down 39 points. S&P is down one point, and the NASDAQ is higher by three points that's off of the highs of the morning. This, as U.S.-China trade hangs in the balance and weaker-than-expected manufacturing data came out of Europe this morning. Joining us right now is Northern Trust Wealth Management CIO Katie Nixon. Katie, it's good to have you.

KATIE NIXON, CIO, NORTHERN TRUST WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Let me just point out that the China ministry finance -- the China Ministry of Commerce issued -- pardon me -- issued a statement calling last week's talks, constructive, whatever that means. You did have this week, Eurozone PMIs out this morning. And we are looking for the rest of today when we get the September flash PMIs At 9:45. We'll see what that means for manufacturing. Having said all of that, how do you invest in this environment?

NIXON: Lots of news to digest, clearly. The news on China, it's sort of more of the same. We've been here many, many times. We're not expecting there to be any meaningful resolution. Prior -- really probably prior to the 2020 election, we do think we might have interim deals, despite what President Trump said on Friday where he said we were only going to be a big-bang deal. I think both sides probably want to see some progress.

In terms of PMI data, I mean, Europe is week. We've been talking about that for a long time. It's not surprising, but it's deepening. And certainly, when you have the engine of growth in Europe, Germany facing such dire manufacturing numbers, clearly very influenced by the global sort of slow down and auto automobile manufacturing. That's not a good sign for Europe. And, you know what, Draghi seem to have gotten it right when he did his big bazooka couple of weeks ago and really pulled out all the stops in front of what is really proving to be a really weak scenario.

PEEK: But isn't it amazing that with the E.U. generally being so, as you say, Draghi being so openhanded and everything else, and yet Germany passes this green program, which is tens of billions of euros, and yet, they're going to raise taxes to pay for it. And I think everyone in the world except Germans are saying, are you kidding? Why would you not have at least some borrowing at negative interest rates to fund something like that, and make it a stimulative measure?

NIXON: You know what, Liz, it's real head scratcher, to be honest. Because when you think about the green -- the climate deal in Europe, 52 billion euro, the multiplier is not one for one in terms of stimulus, it's actually less than one because the deal is going to be relatively expensive. And it's probably going to increase energy costs. So, net-net, it doesn't look like a positive exactly at the time when the pressure is on for some sort of stimulus. The good news is that Merkel affirmed her belief in a balanced budget. So, they still do have some wiggle room because they have a surplus right now. But 2-1/2, 2.4 2.5 percent of GDP. So, there is some wiggle room there, and we think they're going to have to use it. Again, politicians don't act outside of crisis, Liz.

(CROSSTALK)

NIXON: We'll see. You know, Germany is in a technical recession. And I think that, you know, the politicians will have to act.

PAYNE: And kind of play off that, too. I mean, OK, we know it's slow. Like you said, that's not new news to anybody, but I always look at valuations. They're just so attractive in Europe right now. Dividend yields are really attractive versus where they're getting on negative- yielding debt. What's your view on Europe as an investment right now while the news is bad?

NIXON: So, we prefer us assets over European equities right now. And I'll tell you, one of the issues with looking at European valuations is they're very heavily influenced by financials.

PAYNE: Yes.

NIXON: And financials are just cheap. And they're cheap for a reason. And I think Draghi is trying to address the pain that he's inflicted on financials with negative interest rates through the tearing, that's going to take some time. But Europe is just overbanked, and you know, we're starting to see some of that rationalization take place, but it's going to take some time. Meanwhile, we see, as you said, U.S. is doing great. U.S. earnings are looking to be much more positive in 2020.

BARTIROMO: What are you expecting for the third-quarter earnings?

NIXON: You know, it's going to be rough, Maria, third-quarter is going to be flat, some would even suggest down.

BARTIROMO: So things pick up in the fourth quarter?

NIXON: Things will pick up into in the fourth quarter, and then it's all relative, right? So, comparisons in 2020 will be my easier. I mean, it's really a technology and an energy story.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Because there's this new Gallup Poll, which is out this morning, reveals Americans are not so confident, 49 percent of Americans asked think a recession could be likely in the next year. It's just a speculation, or do you think that there actually are reasons to believe that the recession could happen in the next year?

NIXON: Well, let's break it down. So, you have sort of financial market indicators and economic indicators. So, economic indicators: services, very strong; consumption, very strong; unemployment, very low; momentum, slowing; jobs creation slowing, but still positive and strong. Financial Markets, you've got credit spreads that are tight, that's a positive. You don't typically see that in front of a recession. The one area that's flashing red would be the yield curve. You've got the three-month, 10-year still inverted, the tooth tends kind of skirting around flat to inverted, slightly -- I guess there's two-basis points positive.

BARTIROMO: Why? I mean, that doesn't always indicate a recession, right, James?

FREEMAN: Well, the frequently signals -- what is it? -- it's like an economist predicted 10 out of the last three recessions and sometimes it can be a false signal. But I'm wondering, how do you price in the possibilities on politics, where we get a German-style environmental regulation, German -- European-style zero-growth economics. You've got Elizabeth Warren surging in the polls. You've got maybe Biden, and then you've got Trump. I mean, how do you price in -- do you think markets have priced in the possibilities here? How do you look at that?

NIXON: So, political uncertain -- geopolitical uncertainty is super high. In addition to the ones that you just reference, we have Brexit, we have tensions in the Gulf, the list goes on and on, frankly. So, there's no shortage of geopolitical risk. I mean, there's always geopolitical risk, there just seems to be a lot more right now coming from a lot of different places. And it probably isn't fully priced in into the market.

One of the things like trade risk, for example, it could have a really positive impact on the market. So, it's a really that cuts both ways. It could be a negative if we go to December and have the tariffs put into place, which would be very negative for the U.S. That's a wildcard. But it could be really positive. If we come to some sort of a resolution, you've got global growth that starts to come back. So, some of it isn't -- is not fully priced into the market at this point.

BARTIROMO: By the way, China canceled the planned visits to U.S. farms this week. Lot of people were wondering why that happened at the end of Friday. Bloomberg is reported that that was carried out at the behest of us. And now, people are changing their tune and say, Well, maybe this is a positive.

NIXON: Right.

BARTIROMO: Actually. So, we'll see. It's all speculation until the deal gets done. I know that. Katie, it's great to see you.

NIXON: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much, Katie Nixon joining us there. Coming up, policing big tech, Georgia congressman Doug Collins is one of the lawmakers who met with Facebook's founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg last week, as did of course, the president. BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, September 23rd. Your top stories right now 8:32 a.m. on the East Coast. This is basically back at lows of the morning right now.

Global markets this morning are also lower. As you see, signs of slowing in the Eurozone among the reasons manufacturing sentiment in Europe zone fell in September to the worst level in nearly seven years. And then, there was the Purchasing Managers Indexes, this morning, out of Germany in France. They came in below expectations, showing weakness in manufacturing and that's unnerving stocks.

FT-100 down 21, CAC Quarante down 58, and the DAX Index in Germany is lower by 136 points. That was worse -- that was the worst of them all and it is down better than one percent. In Asia overnight, Japan is closed for a national holiday. The others were mixed. Shanghai Composite the worst performer down almost one percent in China.

The streaming wars deepen; Disney Plus is available for preorder ahead of its big November debut.

And big change at Overstock. The online retailer naming a new CEO and acting CFO. This as China tariffs take a toll on the company; the stock plummeting. The premarket this morning down 14 percent on Overstock.

Plus, living rent-free. A look at why millennials think their parents should let them live at home for nothing, why not? What do you think?

All those stories coming up this Monday morning. But first, our top story this half an hour. President Trump's July phone call with president of Ukraine. The president reportedly pressured his Ukrainian counterpart to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his anti-trust investigations into Ukraine, while his son Hunter Biden was working there. Earlier in the program, I spoke with president's personal attorney and former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani about that call.

GIULIANI: The Democrats, you know, wanted to impeach when it was quid pro quo and money, now there's no quid pro quo, no money -- proper action by a president, they might say improper, but certainly not grounds for impeachment. As the story gets less serious, as the story disappears, they still want to impeach. So, I hope the American people get the point. They want to impeach, doesn't matter.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Now, we know that.

GIULIANI: Here is the problem for them: even if you take the first story, about the president, but Biden did as much worse.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Georgia Congressman, House Judiciary Committee Ranking Member Doug Collins. And Congressman, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks so much for your time this morning.

REP. DOUG COLLINS (R-GA): Thanks Maria, it's good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So, let me ask you about this Ukraine call, I mean, Rudy Giuliani was just on with me, he said a lot of things there, particularly about Joe Biden and Hunter Biden. Is this phone call between the president and the president of Ukraine going to be a problem for President Trump?

COLLINS: I think right now it's just another issue that the Democrats have latched onto, and it's amazing to me, Maria, and I was listening to part of that interview that you had with me with Mr. Giuliani, it's amazing to me the different standards the Democrats are now using.

Any time something comes up that they don't like with the president, they're saying, well, you need to prove that you didn't do anything wrong. When did that become the standard?

It's become the standard for this president where he has to prove that he didn't do anything wrong, simply because they don't like what is going on or they think there's suspicion of something that could actually -- they could latch onto.

They've latched onto nothing so far and I think what's going to become the story is more of what Mr. -- former Vice President Biden did. I think what we're seeing here is a leader who is talking to another leader. It is concerning how these continually from the intelligence communities get leaked out. So, we're going to see how this comes forward. But again, it's just a different standard for this president compared to anybody else in the country.

BARTIROMO: Well, it is really hard to ignore the double standard here, especially as we are just coming off of two and half years where the entire public was out of their minds over Russia collusion. And there too, it was based on anonymous conversation, speculation, when in fact we know at the end of the day it was the Democrats who worked with the Russians to try to get dirt on President Trump.

COLLINS: Oh yes, the only true collusion that we found was the Democrats and the Russians in this but nobody wants to talk about that. In fact, we even found out last Friday and I think we've been trying to put this out there that we actually saw now evidence of Mr. McCabe in the discussions about wearing a wire tap. The start of the collusion issue came with Mr. McCabe. These are the kind of things that Democrats want to ignore.

They want to go back to a report that they've not seen, a transcript they've not seen to a report that is contingently at this point just simply speculative. But yet, trying to make the president prove something didn't happen. This is really where we got to go back to what actually did happen.

We know that there was a corrupt cabal of the DOJ. I didn't see the outrage then. It's all about this president and their focus on getting him.

BARTIROMO: So, are you going to be able to cut through the noise then and actually report the wrongdoing and actually see accountability for some of this? And what do we know about this whistleblower? What can you tell us?

COLLINS: Well, that's a great question because nobody knows at this point. It's all speculation. But it has been a whirlwind stirred up by the Democrats and frankly their willing accomplices in the media. The media has helped amplify every story that they've had.

Adam Schiff has proven, you know, to be frankly a liar on many different levels. When he says that there was collusion, then says that there was something wrong. My chairman is -- went out on a limb and said, oh there's always -- here, we can impeach him now. No, they can't.

And I think the problem here is that they get amplified with the media, who also went out there with them thinking impeachment was going to happen and now they're having to back track. What we're going to do is keep telling the truth.

I think that that's the best thing that you can do with the American people, is say here's what actually happened, here's what's going on, here's what the president is doing for the rest of the world and for our country. Let's focus on this, and focus on what actually happened instead of the speculation that has turned into nothing.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, let me switch gears and ask you about the crackdown on big tech. Facebook co-founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg met with the president at the White House on Thursday. You met with Zuckerberg as well on Capitol Hill on Friday.
