Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SYY-8WN1-DXH2-603P-00000-00China Trade Tensions; Sen. Warren (D-MA) Said She's Not Afraid To Be The Underdog; Philadelphia Police Officer Shot In The Face While Serving A Warrant; Explosion In Italy; Trade In Turmoil2018-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTLee Carter, Mitch Roschelle, Mike Baker, Mark Penn, Paul ChristopherNEWSFinancial080603cb.231China Trade Tensions; Sen. Warren (D-MA) Said She's Not Afraid To Be The Underdog; Philadelphia Police Officer Shot In The Face While Serving A Warrant; Explosion In Italy; Trade In TurmoilDagen McDowell, Blake Burman, Kristina Partsinevelos, Nicole Petallides; Stuart Varney

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 6th, your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough talk on trade. China firing back against President Trump. The state media blasting the administration, saying extortion won't work. The President Trump, doubling down on his policies over the weekend at a rally in Ohio.

Checking the markets, let's check. You know what is going for President Trump? His rhetoric on trade it's working, he has his base fired up Lee Carter is going to talk about that, coming up. And also, this economy, it's in Fuego. And the futures are showing that this morning.

We have gained across the board. This coming off the fifth week in a row that the Dow and S&P have been up, and the real winner has been the NASDAQ in terms of top performance. It was up nearly one percent on the week. Apple, hitting a $1 trillion market cap. The first U.S. company to ever do that.

All of this in terms of wages growing at the fastest pace in 10 years. Inflation still tame, you name it. It's going well for the United States of America. In Europe, we have gains across the board to tell you about. And England, France, and Germany, no we don't, the markets have completely turned in the other direction. We have losses at the moment.

In Asia, overnight it was mixed action. The Shanghai composite the worst performer there. The Hang Seng managing to eke out a gain of half of one percent.

Earnings season rolls on. SeaWorld and Tyson among the names reporting this morning. What is driving stocks higher? Coming up. Try earnings growth north of 24 percent. That's much better than analysts expected to start the reporting season.

A heroic rescue caught on camera. Atlanta police pull a man out of a burning car. More of the unbelievable video later this hour. Samsung set to unveil its latest iPhone rival. Images of the new device leaked, Samsung is behind it. And it's party time for one panda. A zoo celebrating the first birthday of its newest edition with a cake made of bamboo and fruit.

All of that and so much more coming up this morning. Maslansky and Partner President Lee Carter, PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle, and former CIA operative and Diligence president, Mike Baker. I had to cut you off because we're up against a hard break. But I agree that Conor McGregor it is the fight of - - maybe the century so far, coming up.

MIKE BAKER, PRESIDENT, DILIGENCE: Yes, actually --

MCDOWELL: And it but they got to keep them from getting in trouble because the issue you were talking about is he was -- he threw a hand truck and a van full of fighters out at the bar at the Barclays Center out in Brooklyn, and he ended up being on the legal trouble.

BAKER: Yes, no, look, he is a beast but -- you know, you can do a little home predictable so I think they're going to try to manage -- you know, this is lead up to the fight because this, I had a massive fight, the payday is huge.

If you're talking about China, it's true, quick.

MCDOWELL: Yes, please, quick.

BAKER: I think, people need to watch what China is saying right now. They're ratcheting up the rhetoric a little rhetoric a little bit, and it's becoming more personal which is not typical for them. So, I think what we're seeing from that is their reaction to what's happening within their own economy.

And this is a very interesting time, but also a very difficult time. And we need to manage this properly because again, and we talked about this earlier, a destabilized Chinese economy is not going to do us any good in the long run.

MCDOWELL: Rhetoric that becomes increasingly personal against the president.

BAKER: Against the administration, against President Trump.

MCDOWELL: Because we know he has talked about Xi Jinping, his friend. But --

BAKER: Who is president for life basically now?

MCDOWELL: Right, but -- you know, you start making it personal with President Trump and things generally don't go well. So --

(CROSSTALK)

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Yes, but that thing said, people really think that the president is doing the right thing by fan of China, they're still supporting this on both like on all sides. To say they expect them like two-thirds of Americans think this is the right strategy.

MCDOWELL: And my issue is and I've been very vocal about it. In the meantime, we've taken aback to our allies at the same time. And in Americans whose jobs are at risk or have been hurt by higher prices.

So, there you go. Let's talk China going in on Trump's tariff threats, saying, he's starring in his own, "Streetfighter style, deceitful drama of extortion and intimidation."

The president plans to stay the course on trade. Let's go to Blake Burman live in Berkeley Heights, New Jersey near where the president is taking a working vacation. Blake, what's the latest?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Dagen. Good morning to you. As you guys were just talking about the Chinese ratcheting up the rhetoric over the weekend. The latest coming in a state-run editorial of the -- that editorial described the president as engaging in what they described as "Streetfighter style, deceitful drama of extortion, and intimidation."

The president though over the weekend saying that he gets along with the Chinese.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Look, I don't blame China. I don't blame any of these countries, I don't have to go through them I've got some good relationships. Believe it or not they all like me, they understand. They can't believe themselves they got away with it. They can't believe that they got away with, but they have and we're turning it around, we're turning it around fast.

BURMAN: Both sides appear to be dug in here, because the Chinese saying that the U.S. and China right now are engaged in a quote, "zero-sum" game. While members of the Trump administration continue to say that President Trump will not blink.

JOHN BOLTON, UNITED STATES NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR: Don't underestimate President Trump's resolve here.

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: How far are you prepared to take those?

BOLTON: Far enough to get China to change its behavior, and they need to understand that.

WALLACE: And, if they don't change their behavior?

BOLTON: I think, the pressure will continue. I think the president's made that very clear.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BURMAN: The president, now unveiling a new argument over the weekend Dagen, he tweeted out the following at one point, writing, "Because of tariffs, we will be able to start paying down large amounts of the $21 trillion in debt that has been accumulated. It's unclear though, Dagen, exactly how that specific math there checks out? Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Blake. Blake Burman for us in New Jersey.

BURMAN: We got it.

MCDOWELL: Joining us now, Mark Penn, a former Clinton adviser Stagwell Group president, author of the book Microtrends Squared. Mark, I said earlier as a person, I consider myself to be a fiscal conservative. I don't think, I've ever seen a Republican president in my lifetime brag about tax increases because that's essentially what he was doing. And it's actually not the first time I've heard him say that at least, one of the rallies recently.

MARK PENN, FORMER ADVISER OF BILL CLINTON: Well, I think you have to look at these tariffs as strategic bargaining chips. I mean, I think, you know what, I've seen President Trump do over and over again is when he doesn't really have anything to bargain with, he creates things to bargain with.

And that's what I think what he's done with the tariffs. And when it comes to China, the public really does support him in China. They think China has been stealing American jobs for a long time, stealing American technology, and is out for world economic domination on the back of America.

CARTER: You know, Mark, this is Lee Carter speaking. I am -- I'm fascinated by how Americans are reacting to all of this. And really -- in general saying that they support what the president is doing with China, and believe exactly what you said that these are really strategic bargaining chips that he's using with. And think in a long-term, we're going to win.

And we're seeing the president's approval ratings eke up. On the other hand, we're seeing independents starting to -- in the most recent polls we thought were just talking about NBC poll that just came out saying that the independents are actually softening towards the president. What are you seeing in your polls?

PENN: Well, look, we had at the Harvard caps, Harris Poll. We had the president at about 45 percent approval. We didn't really show dramatic change. I think to the extent, the president is sticking up it's because of the economic straight.

70 percent of Americans now say that we have a strong economy, and that really is the biggest change in the poll in the last year.

I think that's up about 15 points or so. And that is the tremendous shift, and that is what is holding him up because he's got a 55 percent approval there. On the other side, immigration -- you know, the tariffs, he could have waited till after the midterms on the tariffs because it does create - - you know, some controversy particularly in terms of Europe and Mexico, and but not China, they do support him on China. And that's kind of what we're saying.

CARTER: You know, the other thing that I'm really, really interested in when it comes to the -- comes to the polling is voter enthusiasm. And as we're going into the midterms, it's sort of been flip-flopping over who's more enthusiastic, Democrats or Republicans?

And as we're looking at the war on the media or the media -- you know, back and forth between the president, and it seems like the war on what's happening with the media, and the media attacking the president all the time, did he energizing Republicans more? What do you see?

PENN: Yes, I think everybody is going to be energized. I am going to be fascinating, we're going to be fascinated about what happens on Tuesday night here in this -- in this special election in a Republican district in Ohio.

I -- look, I think that the president has made the choice here energize his base. Go out and rally after rally, and do what worked for him in the presidential.

A little risky because the question is, "Are independent women in suburban districts who have voted more Republican than anybody realizes going to drift Democratic? And that's really the big question. And the more he plays to the base, to the working class that doesn't typically show out, the show up in midterms, the more he may lose some of the well-educated suburban voters who typically do.

MCDOWELL: But, Mark, I will say this, and we saw it in 2016. Women, wives, mothers vote on the economy. This economy is growing at the fastest pace in four years north of four percent it could grow even faster in the current quarter based on the most recent estimates.

Job growth on average this year is faster than it was last year at this time which is incredible for an economy into nine years of an expansion. Wages are growing at the fastest pace in a decade. And then, you have good news even on Obamacare in premiums aren't going up as much as people expected. They're actually falling according to reports to some of these state insurance commissioners.

I think that it's hard to find anything wrong. This is -- and look at this, the USDA showed that nearly 3 million Americans have come off of food stamps since President took office. Again, that's what women vote on.

PENN: Well, and of course, if I were working with President Clinton, and we had numbers like that, his ratings would be in the stratosphere and he'd be untouchable. So, the fact that's not the case shows you that, that message hasn't gotten through yet.

Certainly, the idea that 3 million are off food stamps hasn't gotten through. It's an important message because the big question here with the tax cuts is, "Did it just benefit the big corporations or did the working class and even the working poor benefit? And truth is that you say a lot of statistics are coming out.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Do you need the message? Do you need the messages, though? 90 percent of Americans got a pay hike because of the tax cuts earlier this year. 90 percent of people are seeing fatter paychecks. Do you need to message that?

Do -- there -- again, it kind of comes back to do his approval ratings and do the polls even matter because they sure as heck didn't matter going into the election almost two years ago?

PENN: Well, but the public is fed up, the Congress doesn't seem to be able to do anything. I do think the Republicans have a leader who has quit, doesn't even support the President on tariffs. And yet, is staying in office. I've said consistently with you that I think the biggest Republican weakness is they have no message and the leadership.

The Democrats have weaknesses too. You know, headed by Pelosi, someone who's really disliked throughout the country and featuring socialist. That's why a voter who is going to go into the polls who's not energized in the middle is truly confused about which way to vote.

MCDOWELL: Well, you said, Nancy Pelosi, let's also talk about Senator Elizabeth Warren, which she was fueling rumors of a presidential run over the week and saying, she well -- you can just listen to this, she's not afraid to be the underdog.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA), SENATE ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE: It won't be easy. We're going to have to fight uphill. But me, I'm going up that hill and I hope you are too. And I hope that when you do, you'll reach your hand out and bring someone else along for the climb.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: In terms of policy platform, it's abortion and open borders. I don't know how that wins.

PENN: Well, if you look at the Democrats in the Democratic primary, actually, Biden has been rising and not Elizabeth Warren. Elizabeth Warren gets all the publicity, but he went out -- you know, this week with President Obama.

You know, I think begin -- he has been very quietly position himself. Look, I don't think Elizabeth Warren would be the best Democratic presidential candidate. And -- you know, the Pelosi Warren team is really too far to the left for America.

But I don't think that's where the rank-and-file Democrats are, and I don't think that's how this is going to play out come three years from now.

MCDOWELL: Joe Biden taking a selfie with President Obama with a big grin on his face. Well, I think that every American could write the caption for that. Mark Penn, thank you so much.

PENN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you my friend, Mark Penn. Coming up, an unbelievable rescue. Police in Atlanta pull a man out of a burning car. Details on the heroic action straight ahead. And Samsung unveiling its newest phone this week. The detail is already out because Samsung leaked them. That story later this hour.

MCDOWELL: Breaking news. A Philadelphia Police Officer is in the hospital after being shot in the face this morning. Kristina Partsinevelos has the details. Kristina?

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes. The officer was shot in the face while serving a warrant. He is identified as 49-year-old Jason Potts. A 20-year veteran of the force and a member of the SWAT team. Officer Potts suffered heavy bleeding and at least a broken jaw. Police say he is expected to survive though.

Tourists are fleeing after a powerful earthquake in Indonesia. Magnitude 7.0 quake hitting the tourist island of Lombok killing about 100 people. More than 230 others seriously injured. The death toll is expected to rise and search operations continue. It's the second deadly -- deadliest quack in just one week to hit that island. A July 29th quake killed 16 people and damaged hundreds of homes.

And there is more trouble at Wells Fargo. The bank said the calculation error may have caused hundreds of people to lose their homes to foreclosure between 2010 and 2015. According to a regulatory filing, Wells Fargo said the mistake was made in a formula used to qualify struggling homeowners for Federally-backed assistance programs. The bank has set aside $8 million or about $20,000 per affected customer.

Shares of Wells Fargo are down three percent today but up this morning. And PepsiCo CEO announcing plans to step down after leading the company for 12 years. Indra Nooyi will leave in October and she will be succeeded by Ramon Laguarta. Nooyi, a 24-year old veteran at PepsiCo will remain chairman at the board until early next year. Shares of PepsiCo slightly in premarket trading. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Kristina. Extremely tough job, Mitch Roschelle. And at the time that Pepsi is under pressure in terms of its fizzy drinks business but also with these tariffs.

ROSCHELLE: And took global business and just not operating and selling your product to consumers and business in one country, selling around the world and that's a challenging job by any stretch with tariffs, it's even more complicated.

MCDOWELL: Right. And trade spats that are --

ROSCHELLE: And currencies that are not moving in the direction people that people thought they were moving, so --

MCDOWELL: Right. It's very difficult to plan your business that way but a great run for a well-known woman at the top of one great American company.

CARTER: She is an extraordinary leader with an extraordinary vision.

MCDOWELL: You -- I want to give you a quiz. I hate when people do this but Pepsi was invented where? Coke was invented in Atlanta. Where was Pepsi invented? New Bern, North Carolina, Mitch Roschelle.

BAKER: Oh, you think it was time to answer her.

MCDOWELL: And he didn't know.

ROSCHELLE: OK. I wrote it down right here, New Bern, North Carolina.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Yes. That's right. Thank you so much. Coming up. A whale sized surprise. Seaworld reporting better-than-expected sales. The stock jumping on the news. A closer look at what people back to the park straight ahead. Plus, a birthday bash fit for a giant panda. A zoo celebrates its newest bear cub with a cake of bamboo and fruit.

MCDOWELL: Social media gets political again. Twitter apologizing after it suspended conservative commentator Candace Owens for response to a set of anti-white tweets by New York Times editorial board member. This is a new higher. This as reports indicate executives and top board members from the social media giant have donated overwhelmingly to Democrats.

Lee, your reaction to this. Candace Owens basically took anti-white tweets from this new hire by the New York Times and replaced certain her words in as -- to illustrate the insanity and hideousness of what this woman at The New York Times had been tweeting. That woman said that it was -- I guess she was trying to illustrate irony or something like that. Nevertheless, your reaction.

CARTER: So my reaction is A, she should not have been suspended, B, I can understand from a machine learning perspective how this could have been taken down as hate speech. But what I don't understand is why it just would have been blocked like so many other things or rather than saying that we're going to suspend her. And thirdly, I really think that if this is going to be the policy of a social media company like Twitter they need to be able to respond more quickly.

To have this happen for 12 hours, to go with no response, to go and say nothing for a long time is a real problem for them and when I think that Twitter really needs to remember is that, there is a huge number of conservatives between ages 27 and 32. In fact there was more conservatives than there are liberals. So they better do something about this.

MCDOWELL: It's become -- Mike, how do you feel of about this? Because I have noticed and I mentioned with Jessica Tarlov that conservatives have put in a bright red X next to their names to push back on Twitter, their way of expressing dissatisfaction with the shadow banning that we've been going on like where in search results, conservative names are essentially buried or don't even show up at all.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. Look, I'm shocked that Twitter leadership overwhelmingly supports Democrats. I picked up the New York Times, I know I'm reading a paper with a certain lean, right? I pick up the Wall Street Journal same way. You know, it's the world we live in. I get on Twitter, I know where they're going, right? I know what their agenda in a sense is, and so I'm not surprised.

And -- I guess bigger issue for me is just we -- where is the civility in any of the dialogue whether it's on social media or face to face or on, you know, traditional media. We seem to have lost the inability, right? To speak rationally speak to people having a different point of view. We've lost our --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Here are the two things -- the most hideous things that have been said to me on Twitter by people on left, they need to reopen Auschwitz to gas and incinerate you and I can't wait until Iran wipes Israel off the map so I can watch you cry. These people were not disciplined by Twitter, they shouldn't have accounts, should they?

It's a private organization, they should -- but again, the level of hate -- and these are people, who -- go by their own names who were sitting at home spewing this kind of hatred and if I --

(CROSSTALK)

BAKER: But it's on both sides. It's on both -- to be honest it's -- both the hard sides, right? Both the far right, the far left are sitting in their trenches throwing hand grenades saying equally despicable things. Nobody exists in the center anymore. You don't have to agree with somebody's position, right? You don't have to read -- you're just fine. But figure out a way to have a conversation without being --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You know, on the left anti-semitism is alive and well and I don't even -- and they don't -- people, liberals don't acknowledge it, I see it every day and I can say with no hesitation that the nastiest that ever been said to me on social media were from the left. People who preach -- you know, 40 years ago preaching peace, love, and happiness. Let's all locked arms and we are against big government and helping one another.

Well, that just died. I don't know when but it just died.

ROSCHELLE: Well, no doubt about it. I mean, Antifa, the big joke about them is that they think they are, you know, this group that's out to, you know, to promote free speech and yet they bludgeon anybody who doesn't agree with them. And they don't get the joke about that, they don't see how ironic that is.

MCDOWELL: And cowards wearing black masks, I should point that out. Cowards wearing -- covering their faces.

BAKER: You're not a good look for them.

MCDOWELL: Coming. A massive pile up twisted steel and metal left behind after freight train derails in Pittsburgh. The latest on the investigation into that crash. Plus, Samsung's new Galaxy Note 9 details leaked from Samsung. We will tell you what happened.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 6th, your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. China state media attacks President Trump, over his proposed tariffs. Look out a state-run paper calling the tariffs extortion saying that president is starring in his own street fighter style defeatful drama. President Trump says that the tariffs are all about getting America on track.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: But America's economic surrender ended the day that I took office, folks. Now after years of rebuilding foreign countries, we are finally rebuilding our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Mike Baker said look out because China is getting all the more personal, and when people make personal attacks on President Trump -- we've kind of seen that movie before, we know what happens to them.

Futures are showing a flat market at the start of trading to start this new week. We have some slight gains on the Dow, S&P, and NASDAQ 100 futures. But last week, the Dow and S&P up for their fifth week in a row. The NASDAQ, bright shining star is well up more than one percent.

In Europe, we've been watching markets. We've been touting between green and red gains, now some losses across the board in England, France, and Germany, although slight loses. In Asia overnight, the market's mostly lower as well. The Seoul winner, with the Hang Seng up half of one percent.

And explosion near an airport in Italy. Police are tweeting that it was caused by an accident on a highway. We'll bring you the latest from Italy. And a nightmare on the tracks. A Norfolk southern train derailed in Pittsburgh yesterday. We bring you the details from this tragedy. Hero caught on video. Body cam footage showing an Atlanta police officer making a daring rescue from a burning car.

And hold the phone. New details out from Samsung on their latest phone we will break it down. And unbearably cute, a panda in France, celebrates his first birthday. Complete with a cake. Made of fruit and bamboo. We will play panda videos and baby goat videos all day long.

To our top story this half hour. Markets shaking up trade tensions. President Trump using the stock market as a measure of who's winning the trade dispute, and indicating that U.S. has a clear lead over China. Listen to this:

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If I didn't do anything with the trade deals, if I said nothing, we're going to let everybody continue to take our jobs, take our wealth, let them continue -- you know, I bet our stock market is up almost 40 percent since I won. But if I didn't do anything with trade, just kept quiet, let them continue to take advantage of us. Nobody says anything. I think you would've been up another 40, 50, 60 percent. But eventually, you would have had to pay the piper eventually, and we're not going to do. We're going to do something, we're going to make our country so much richer than it has ever been.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now: Paul Christopher, Wells Fargo Investment Institute Head Global Market Strategist. Paul, why has the markets been able to shake off the trade tensions, the trade worry so much?

PAUL CHRISTOPHER, HEAD GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO INVESTMENT INSTITUTE: Well, though, the market believes and we agree, that a deal is the ultimate goal here that the goal is not to run the Chinese economy into the ground or the U.S. economy into ground with unending tariffs. They can get a negotiation on the trade deficit, getting the Chinese to buy more from this country, and if they can get a deal on autos with the Mexicans, the Canadians, and the Europeans then we think the trade talk, the rhetoric, dies down a bit or is dialed back.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC U.S.: Hey, Paul, Mitch Roschelle. You mentioned China and their economy, some of the challenges that their economy sort of predate the trade war, their markets are sort of in free- fall, their currency is diminishing, and they are growing middle class, and the funding of entitlements for the middle class is really starting to put pressure on their ability to grow and you see that in GDP numbers. So, regardless, don't we still have a global challenge that China's economy that's going to impact other global economies if this trade war isn't sorted out.

CHRISTOPHER: Well, you're absolutely right, Mitch, the moderation in growth around the world, Europe I mention, too had slowed down some. That is confusing the markets a little bit here. They're thinking that all of the slowdown is related to trade talk. It's not. The slowdown is predating the trade talk and it's an important factor. The Chinese -- we need to remember, the Chinese have an economy that on the one hand, has very strong consumer growth, and on the other hand has a lot of debt. And as you mentioned, some issues with the providing social welfare. So, how are they going to balance that going forward? They need to be very careful with that and they don't need extra variable in there, if you will, of trade uncertainty. So, we think there's pressure on Chinese internally to come to the negotiating table.

MCDOWELL: Debt is a huge issue, though, Paul. And let's talk about what we're paying as nation to borrow right now. JPMorgan Chase CEO, Jamie Dimon, warning investors over the weekend to prepare for five percent interest rates -- that would be yield on the 10-year treasury. And this certainly is a major concern; it's not showing up in the markets so much at this point, but now that back to running one trillion-dollar deficits, we're in a fight with one of the largest holders of our own debt. Someone we've leaned on China and relied upon to buy our debt and fund deficit. Your reaction to this? Is there any way in the near-term that we even get back to four percent on the 10-year yield?

CHRISTOPHER: We don't think that there's much chance of getting to back to four percent any time soon. On the 10-year yield, yes, the debt is a weight on the economy, call it a headwind for growth. And no, we don't think the Chinese are about ready to dump their holdings of U.S. Treasuries. Treasuries are simply the largest, the most liquid market in the world. And if you're a government that needs to hold trillions of dollars of reserves, there's no other place for you to go but to hold U.S. Treasury.

So, we don't think there's a real threat there. But yes, the debt is going to be a headwind for the economy going forward. On the other hand, you've got, still, quite a demographic challenge going forward as many of us age and get into the retirement years. We're going to be holding a lot more debt anyway, that's going to help keep yield a little lower. Our target for 10-year treasury of this year is in the low threes, and we don't see it moving up to four any time soon -- rather low yields look to us to be continue to be the main problem for investors.

MCDOWELL: Well, is an aging population and those who will be holding more safe, if you will, treasuries, is that bad for the stock market then?

CHRISTOPHER: Well, what it does for the stock market when the yields are low, relatively low on treasury, we've been hanging around three percent here. That means that you can have a little bit higher stock market prices, before stocks get overvalued. So, we don't think that stocks are too rich right now, and part of that argument is that the 10-year is just not making the sort of headway that would get you to four or five percent. If we were to see that, we'd be more worried about stocks.

BAKER: Paul, going book to -- sorry, Mike Baker, here, going back to tariffs question: There's a bit of a -- softening in the talk between U.S. administration, and the E.U. now, and tariffs skirmish. Do you expect the same development in our conversations with China?

CHRISTOPHER: Well, the I think Chinese know that there's a deal available for them any time they want to take it. But they're just not sure whether, whether they should go now or later. We think there will be a deal sometime. There's a good window for that opening up in the fall. But the Chinese simply need to figure out a way to close that -- some of that trade deficit. They could buy more liquid natural gas, they could buy more crude oil, they could buy more soybeans. Certainly, they need all of those things in greater quantities than before.

And I think if they were to do that, they would make -- they would come a long way towards meeting the president in a deal. So, I think that's, in the end, where they'll finally go is making some kind of deal on trade. The U.S. and the Europeans also have talking to do, not a done deal yet there either. But, again, the president probably wants to see those two things, some sort of deal on autos and some sort of deal with the Chinese on the trade deficit. And then we think that the trade negotiations seem to a lower priority and for the markets and we can get back to thinking about good earnings growth going forward.

MCDOWELL: Paul, real quick, why is the opening in terms of having discussions with China, why is that in the fall what about the timing of that?

CHRISTOPHER: Well, the -- you've got midterm elections coming up here --

MCDOWELL: Right.

CHRISTOPHER: -- In U.S. And the president is still putting out their additional tariffs and the Chinese feel obliged to respond. I think they're still gauging each other's degree of seriousness that the president in our view, since the beginning, has been serious. But some people maybe have been thinking that, well, he would be eventually bend or making exceptions. That's not been the case. So, they need to get back talking again. There's some evidence that the Chinese are interested in that. It just has to happen sometime in the next few months, we thing.

MCDOWELL: And the stock market just keeps chugging along. Paul Christopher, thank you so much. Take care.

CHRISTOPHER: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Come back soon. Coming up, incredible rescue caught on tape. A police officer in Atlanta pulls a man out of a burning car. You have to see more of this hero in action. Plus, Amazon, Google, Microsoft, all aiming to be the next to join Apple at a $1 trillion valuation. Stuart Varney makes a big prediction about those tech titans. Mitch Roschelle is going hmm, we all are. Mr. Varney is next.

MCDOWELL: Second quarters earning season rolls on this week at a slower pace. But Tyson Foods and Sea World have reported this morning. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Monday morning, Dagen. So, there's been a lot of optimism surrounding the earnings 24.2 percent gain for earnings overall, year-over-year growth. So, that's surpassing analysts' estimates in 43 companies this week. Take a look at two that have already kicked it out: Tyson Foods and Sea World. Sea World up 15 percent; Tyson Food up three percent, this morning. So, Tyson Foods CEO, we did see that Tyson Foods -- this was a beat on profit. Also, the cattle prices have been falling; the food prices have been falling, and they've increased herd size, and size of the heavier animals. That offset the impact of falling bacon pork prices. This is apparent of Ball Park Frank's hot dogs and Jimmy Dean's sausages.

And then, there's Sea World. What the CEO is saying that the quarter benefitted from new marketing initiatives, strategic pricing, positive reception to rises and such, the attendance on rise, and it was the revenue that wowed Wall Street. In fact, this is the third time in a row, third straight, beat on top lines. So, this is a winner, no doubt, for Sea World. And you could see it is up 15 percent. That's going to be heavily traded in a big mover today.

Just as far as market commentary, Jeff Saut over at Raymond James, everybody's been somewhat concerned about the sector rotation out of tech - - out of tech and out of consumer cyclicals, and have they moved into cash? No, in fact, they've moving been moving it into industrials and financials, and some other consumer non-cyclicals. And he said, this sector rotation is healthy, it's associated with a healthy bull market. They're also a little positive on Apple, and little weak on CBS this morning. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Nicole. Apple, the first to cross the finish line to $1 trillion in its valuation. Several other big tech names are close behind. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney. You have a prediction, sir?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Oh, wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute. I just want to take our audience back to the Fox News Channel on Friday afternoon where you made a stellar appearance on "THE FIVE," as I recall. I thought you were really, really cool. And it occurred to me, you and I go back about 10 years now, working together in the Fox Business Network for about 10 years. What's the biggest story that you and I have covered in those 10 years? Don't answer, I think --

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: I love you.

VARNEY: I think it is the extraordinary performance and the gain in valuation of those five big technology companies. Apple is already worth a trillion. You've got Google, Amazon, and Microsoft really close, well above 800 billion, and Facebook is down there at 500 billion. But essentially, I've never seen anything like this before. You've never seen the accumulation of wealth and power as we have seen in the last couple of years in those five american technology companies. There's going to be cause to break them up, but nonetheless, they are there, they're exceptionally powerful. I think it's a unique moment in our financial history. Amazon, Google, microsoft, you get a good rally this year, and from where we are now, and all three of them will join Apple at a trillion- dollar valuation, extraordinary stuff.

MCDOWELL: It really is important though, Stuart, that you highlight it in the way that you do every day on your show, but in this -- in this moment as well, and I said this because we very often -- you know, the news media gets criticized so much, but many people are quite frankly lazy about it. They don't have to do any homework, they can talk about President Trump and his mental state. But this is important to breathe and look at and highlight because this is American greatness.

VARNEY: And it doesn't get much coverage in the establishment newpapers.

MCDOWELL: No.

VARNEY: They cover it in a negative way. They've got too much power, they've got too much wealth. I cover it in a positive way. All the money they are making will flow out into different industries like cars, medical devices, drugs, that -- money made out of computing power will flow out to other industries and improve them. I think it's very positive development.

MCDOWELL: And anybody in this country, if you own one share of an Apple or a Microsoft or Amazon, or a Netflix, you're an owner in that company.

VARNEY: Oh, yes.

MCDOWELL: You own part of it and I think that that's worth -- that we're all in it together. We're all part of this greatness.

VARNEY: Anybody with a 401(k), an IRA, a mutual fund, you benefited from this, you've seen your retirement savings go up, and that is wholly good.

MCDOWELL: Amen and hallelujah.

VARNEY: There's a mutual adoration society here, Dagen, I kind of like it.

MCDOWELL: And thank you for the kind words.

VARNEY: You're welcome.

MCDOWELL: That's why we like working here because these are the people we work with and we actually like each other off in here, and not faking it -- we're not faking it.

VARNEY: Incredible.

BAKER: And Stuart --

MCDOWELL: No, we got to go.

BAKER: Oh, we got to go.

MCDOWELL: I love you, Mike. That's Mike Baker.

VARNEY: OK, Mike, love you, too.

(LAUGHTER)

BAKER: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: A reminder, "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts every day at 9:00 a.m. Eastern. He is coming up in almost 11 minutes. A birthday bash fit for a giant panda. A zoo celebrates its newest beer cub with a delicious treat for a party of one.

PARTSINEVELOS: -- tumbling down on a hill on to light rail tracks, so that's what you're seeing in the screen right now, the cars were carrying consumer products but just food and housewares. No injuries luckily have been reported, and an investigation into the derailment is underway. Train service, though, has been suspended in the area.

An Atlanta Police officer is being hailed a hero this morning after saving a passenger from a burning car last night, and it was all caught on his body camera. You can see the officer, he's about to run from the vehicle and is dousing with a fire extinguisher. Authorities say the car's engine went up in flames after the car hit a metal utility pole. Officials say three people were taken to a local hospital. Another officer suffered minor scrapes and bruises. What a video.

Samsung is out with a new sneak peek on its new Galaxy Note 9. The company unveiling this video for the smartphone in its YouTube channel. It all but confirms that the Note 9 will have the option for one terabyte of memory, a massive amount of storage for all those videos and pictures we take. The Note 9 will apparently also come with 512 gigabytes of built in memory and support for 512 gigabytes microsdcards, something not supported by the iPhone, so those are difference right there.

And we have to end the morning of the hour with a lovely video of a french baby panda which treated to a unique cake to celebrate its first birthday, bamboo, honey, and a variety of fruits went into the colorful cake. The young panda weighs about 60 pounds and probably packed a few more after his B-Day celebration.

MCDOWELL: That was in France, so of course, they have a delicious cake.

PARTSINEVELOS: Chocolate cake, yes.

MCDOWELL: Exactly. We need to get your expertise on something when guns did the sports earlier, we had this video of a Mariners fan trying to catch a ball with a bowl of poutine and failing miserably.

CARTER: Oh, no, it's all over the floor. So shameful, shameful.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Please explain what poutine is.

PARTSINEVELOS: Poutine is or just like greasy French fry's gravy and cheese curds. But the cheese curds, when you chew them, they have to be squeeky. And there's an area in Quebec, St. Albert or St. Albert that makes a lot of these cheese curds. They're very popular, you can get all kinds of topings on them, but the one you want to go for is the typical gravy fries and cheese curds. Super fatenning for you.

BAKER: But now, Canada is not claiming they invented cheese curds, are they?

PARTSINEVELOS: No, no, but we didn't --

(CROSSTALK)

CARTER: I'm an American now but (INAUDIBLE) invented the poutine back in the late 1950s.

MCDOWELL: In a trucker.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: See, there's so much shared heritage and love of food between the Canadians and people in the United States.

PARTSINEVELOS: Yes, exactly. That's why I'm here, too. We all get along.

MCDOWELL: So, again, we're build -- we're building some bridges.

PARTSINEVELOS: Yes. I believe that.

MCDOWELL: Tariffs be dammed. We're building culinary --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- we're building culinary bridges.

(CROSSTALK)

BAKER: Over cheese kurds, yes.

PARTSINEVELOS: Yes, exactly. Poutine, yes.

BAKER: Poutine. So, you heard it here. You heard it here. The U.S. and Canada should be allies. OK. Got it.

MCDOWELL: Thank you --

PARTSINEVELOS: I'm glad I'm the expert.

MCDOWELL: Hey, you're killing it today. (INAUDIBLE) the whole nine yards. Kristina Partsinevelos. Coming up, final thoughts from our all stars when we come back.

MCDOWELL: We picked that song because it's one of Mike Baker's top favorite songs of all-time. Final thoughts from our all-stars. Go!

BAKER: Sure. I can confirm that in Boise, we do have the goats gone wild situation under control. It is now safe to go back to Boise, it won't be acoasted by roaming goats. That's all I got.

MCDOWELL: We rank guys -- no, you've got more. Give me something on China real quick.

BAKER: Heading there tomorrow. We'll be back here with you guys in a couple of weeks and we'll be looking forward to talking about what it looks like on the ground there.

MCDOWELL: Are they going to give, are they going to step up and let us actually negotiate different trade deals, Mitch?

ROSCHELLE: The thing that concerns me is growing national debt. We have over $700 billion being refinanced of the next two quarters and that really concerns me.

MCDOWELL: And Federal Reserve is pulling back on its balance sheet at the same time and we're running $1-trillion budget.

ROSCHELLE: This is going to be a trillion-dollar deficit this year.

MCDOWELL: Lee?

CARTER: A lot of criticisms about the polls, and whether or not they're reliable. I think what's important to look at the polls for is for momentum and direction, and it looks like the President has weathered a really tough storm.

MCDOWELL: Indeed, Lee Carter, Mitch Roschelle, and Mike Baker. Thanks to one and all, travel safely, we will see you tomorrer (ph) -- excuse me -- tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts right now. Stuart, it is all yours.

VARNEY: Yes, it is, Dagen, good morning to you, thank you very much, indeed. And good morning, everyone. Investors, how is this to start the week, profit season in full swing, and big companies, their profit is surging.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60VN-JRJ1-JBJ7-N2T1-00000-00China two steps ahead on cyber, says former NSA director2020-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisChina two steps ahead on cyber, says former NSA directorYolanda Redrup

Western nations are wise to block Chinese companies from critical infrastructure projects, according to a former National Security Agency director.

A former head of the US National Security Agency has warned Australia and other Western nations are at a disadvantage in their rising cyber battles with China, because China is willing to take more drastic actions to advance its interests.

Admiral Michael Rogers, who served as the 17th director of the NSA and advised both Barack Obama and current US President Donald Trump, told a Credit Suisse forum on global super trends, that Australia needed to be realistic about the heightened cyber threat posed by China.

"Let's not pretend that these things aren't happening or ignore this activity... We have to acknowledge that they're a competitor that is willing to do things we're not... and who does not automatically go along with the structures we've built [in the last 70 years]," Mr Rogers said.

"I don't think any nation in the world can say right now that they are where they want to be [in terms of their cyber defences].

"Australia has just developed and released a cyber security strategy... and we have to give that time to play out, but all of us need to ask ourselves what we need to be doing differently... We can't keep doing the same thing but expect different results."

Before releasing its cyber strategy Prime Minister Scott Morrison had made a rare declaration that the country was suffering persistent cyber attacks from a "sophisticated state-based actor," which was understood to mean China.

The government said the number of attacks had increased by 330 per cent since the start of the year, and were targeting government, industry, critical industry, education, health and essential services providers.

The theft of intellectual property was considered to be a major motivating factor.

Mr Rogers' remarks came as relations between Australia and China deteriorated last week, when The Australian Financial Review's China correspondent Michael Smith and the ABC's Bill Birtles had to return home after nerve-racking encounters with China's Ministry of State Security.

They were the last two foreign correspondents for Australian news outlets in the country. It also emerged on Monday that a Chinese military contractor has compiled profiles on more than 35,000 prominent Australians, ranging from Prime Minister Scott Morrison to tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes.

The company, Zhenhua Data lists the People's Liberation Army and Communist Party among its main clients and boasts of waging "hybrid warfare" and manipulating reality via social media.

The relationship between Australia and China has frayed substantially since the federal government blocked Chinese telecommunications company Huawei from supplying equipment for the construction of the next-generation 5G mobile network.

The US and UK have followed suit in banning Huawei from their own networks. The US is also forcing ByteDance to sell its US portion of social media app TikTok, or risk it being banned on September 15.

Mr Rogers said a blanket ban on Chinese tech businesses in Western countries would be unnecessary, but he agreed with taking a cautious approach to any business, like Huawei, which is involved in critical infrastructure.

"You have to consider, are you comfortable with the idea of there being Chinese technology in certain aspects of your infrastructure or your broader social constructs," he said.

"It's not a matter of China being bad and the rest of the world being good, but in some areas there is elevated risk to our long-term national security and long-term economic competitiveness in such a way that we should not allow or endorse a China-based solution."

Mr Rogers, who retired from the NSA in January 2018, also weighed in on the possibility of a big tech break-up in the US.

Currently the White House is watching with interest the local competition regulator's push for the tech giants Google and Facebook to pay publishers for news. It was reported earlier this month that Google is facing an antitrust case in the US ahead of the Presidential elections.

Mr Rogers said the current period would test the boundaries between the corporate sector and government, acknowledging that tax laws in particular were formulated in a time when businesses were predominantly "bricks and mortar" and weren't necessarily conducive to the digital age.

But, he cautioned regulators from being too heavy-handed when it came to policing the tech giants.

"If we're not careful and we take this to the extremes, we will kill the geese that have laid the golden eggs," he said.

"I don't think we'll see an immediate break-up per se, but the government is asking some pretty fundamental questions of these companies."

urn:contentItem:60VS-XWC1-JD34-V32C-00000-00China two steps ahead on cyber, says former NSA director;Exclusive2020-09-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisCOMPUTERSPg. 21China two steps ahead on cyber, says former NSA directorExclusiveYolanda Redrup

Australia and other Western nations are at a disadvantage in cyber battles with China because Beijing is willing to take more drastic actions to advance its interests, a former US National Security Agency chief warns.

Australia needs to be realistic about the heightened cyber threat posed by China, Admiral Michael Rogers, a former NSA director who has advised both Barack Obama and Donald Trump, told a Credit Suisse forum on global super trends.

"Let's not pretend that these things aren't happening or ignore this activity ... We have to acknowledge that they're a competitor that is willing to do things we're not ... and who does not automatically go along with the structures we've built [the last 70 years]," he said.

"I don't think any nation in the world can say right now that they are where they want to be [in terms of their cyber defences].

"Australia has just developed and released a cyber security strategy ... but all of us need to ask ourselves what we need to be doing differently ... We can't keep doing the same thing but expect different results."

Prime Minister Scott Morrison earlier made a rare declaration that Australia was suffering persistent cyber attacks from a "sophisticated state-based actor," which was understood to mean China.

The number of attacks had increased more than fourfold since the start of the year, targeting government, industry, critical industry, education, health and essential services providers.

The theft of intellectual property was considered to be a major motivating factor.

Mr Rogers' remarks came as relations between Australia and China deteriorated last week, when The Australian Financial Review's China correspondent Michael Smith and the ABC's Bill Birtles had to return home after interrogations by China's Ministry of State Security. They were the last two foreign correspondents for Australian news outlets in the country. It also emerged on Monday that a Chinese military contractor has compiled profiles on more than 35,000 prominent Australians, ranging from Mr Morrison to Atlassian tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes.

The company, Zhenhua Data lists the People's Liberation Army and Communist Party among clients and boasts of waging "hybrid warfare" and manipulating reality via social media.

The Canberra-Beijing relationship has frayed since the federal government blocked Chinese telco Huawei from supplying equipment to build the next-generation 5G mobile network. The US and UK have followed suit in banning Huawei from their own networks.

The US is also forcing ByteDance to sell its US portion of social media app TikTok, or risk it being banned on September 15.

Mr Rogers said a blanket ban on Chinese tech businesses in Western countries would be unnecessary, but he agreed that taking a cautious approach to any Chinese business, such as Huawei, that is involved in a country's critical infrastructure.

"You have to consider, are you comfortable with the idea of there being Chinese technology in certain aspects of your infrastructure or your broader social constructs," he said.

"It's not a matter of China being bad and the rest of the world being good, but in some areas there is elevated risk to our long-term national security and long-term economic competitiveness in such a way that we should not allow or endorse a China-based solution."

Mr Rogers, who retired from the NSA in January 2018, also weighed in on the possibility of a big tech break-up in the US.

Currently the White House is watching with interest the local competition regulator's push for the tech giants Google and Facebook to pay publishers for news.

It was reported earlier this month that Google is facing an antitrust case in the United States ahead of the scheduled November 3 presidential election.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XFH-MN11-JBHT-D2FN-00000-00China/United States: Some Big Tech Firms Cut Employees' Access to Huawei, Muddying 5G Rollout2019-06-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisGENERAL NEWSChina/United States: Some Big Tech Firms Cut Employees' Access to Huawei, Muddying 5G RolloutBangkokFULL TEXT

Some of the world's biggest tech companies have told their employees to stop talking about technology and technical standards with counterparts at Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd. in response to the recent U.S. blacklisting of the Chinese tech firm, according to people familiar with the matter.

Chipmakers Intel Corp. and Qualcomm Inc., mobile research firm InterDigital Wireless Inc. and South Korean carrier LG Uplus have restricted employees from informal conversations with Huawei, the world's largest telecommunications equipment maker, the sources said.

Such discussions are a routine part of international meetings where engineers gather to set technical standards for communications technologies, including the next generation of mobile networks known as 5G.

The U.S. Department of Commerce has not banned contact between companies and Huawei. On May 16, the agency put Huawei on a blacklist, barring it from doing business with U.S. companies without government approval, then a few days later it authorized U.S. companies to interact with Huawei in standards bodies through August as necessary for the development of 5G standards. The Commerce Department reiterated that position on Friday in response to a question from Reuters.

Nevertheless, at least a handful of major U.S. and overseas tech companies are telling their employees to limit some forms of direct interaction, the people said, as they seek to avoid any potential issues with the U.S. government.

Intel and Qualcomm said they have provided compliance instructions to employees, but declined to comment on them further.

A spokesman for InterDigital said it has provided guidance to engineers to ensure the company is in compliance with U.S. regulations.

An official with LG Uplus said the company is voluntarily refraining from interacting with Huawei workers, other than meeting for network equipment installation or maintenance issues.

Huawei did not provide comment.

5G slowdown

The new restrictions could slow the rollout of 5G, which is expected to power everything from high-speed video transmissions to self-driving cars, according to several industry experts.

At a 5G standards meeting last week in Newport Beach, California, participants privately expressed alarm to Reuters that the long-standing cooperation among engineers that is needed for phones and networks to connect globally could fall victim to what one participant described as a tech war between the U.S. and China.

A representative of a European company that has instituted rules against interaction with Huawei described people involved in 5G development as shaken. This could push everyone to their own corners, and we need cooperation to get to 5G. It should be a global market, the person said.

To be sure, several workers at smaller telecoms firms said they had not been told to avoid discussions with Huawei at standards meetings, and many vendors continue to support existing deals with Huawei. It is unclear how much further communications with Huawei have been curtailed in the tech industry, if at all.

There's been a lot of misunderstanding from what I'm seeing and hearing from clients and colleagues, as far as what the [Commerce Department] restrictions actually entail, said Doug Jacobson, a Washington-based export controls lawyer.

He said that companies prohibiting their employees contacting Huawei was excessive, because the restrictions don't preclude communication, only the transfer of technology.

Huawei, whose equipment the U.S. has alleged could be used by China to spy, has emerged as a central figure in the trade war between the world's two largest economies. Huawei has repeatedly denied it is controlled by the Chinese government, military or intelligence services.

China, U.S, and European companies have split before on standards for Wi-Fi, cell networks and other technologies, and the tit-for-tat over tariffs between Beijing and Washington has increased fears of another bifurcation.

Huawei is a top player at various global organizations that set technical specifications. As one of the world's biggest manufacturers of devices like smartphones, and the vital parts of networks such as routers and switches, Huawei will need to be at the standards-setting table to ensure a seamless customer experience when 5G networks become prevalent, engineers and experts said.

No more informal chats

Engineers and system architects representing their employers at meetings of the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP), a global consortium of industry associations that aims to set 5G specifications by March 2020, often take formal, general discussions into smaller, less documented sessions as they try to find agreement with rivals.

But at 3GPP's meeting last week in California, one of the group's three chairmen, Balazs Bertenyi of Nokia, told attendees that more of those so-called offline conversations than usual would be documented by the standards body with notes and other publicly available records.

It was the practical implication of the new U.S. Commerce Department rules given industry-wide caution despite the exemption for 5G talks, he said.

Companies want to limit informal exchanges, in which their engineers feel more comfortable discussing proprietary technology with rivals to persuade them why their research or innovations are more sound, the sources said.

A separate standards body, the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), put restrictions on Huawei engineers' ability to participate in peer reviews for its publications, drawing criticism from some in China's industry and elsewhere.

The organization, which declined to comment beyond generic statements on its website, then backtracked days later after saying it had received the all-clear from the U.S. Commerce Department with respect to the peer review issue. It did not respond to requests for comment on this story.

Huawei isn't just some company. They, by many accounts, are the leader in 5G technology. Excluding them is very hard to work around, so it does stand to disrupt the entire project, said Jorge Contreras, a law professor at the University of Utah and an IEEE member.

If the idea is to create a non-Chinese 5G, I'm not sure that's possible. Even if it is, would it be as good?

(The Irrawaddy)

urn:contentItem:5W9M-53H1-DYWJ-F00H-00000-00China warns big tech firms against cooperating with the US ban2019-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisChina warns big tech firms against cooperating with the US banDev Kundaliya

Companies that comply with the US sanctions against Huawei could face 'dire consequences', warn Chinese officials

Chinese government officials have warned US technology companies of "serious consequences" for compliance with the Trump administration's sanctions against Huawei.

According to a report by The New York Times, the representatives of several US tech firms were summoned last week in a series of meetings in China. The representatives were told that Trump administration's decision to cut off Chinese companies from American technology had upset the global supply chain and that the companies complying with the policy could face dire consequence.

Cloud & Infrastructure Live 2019 returns to London on 19th September 2019. Learn about the latest technologies in cloud, how to keep one step ahead of the regulators, and network with an audience of IT leaders and senior IT pros. The event will include keynotes, panel discussions, case studies, and strategic and technical streams. Best of all, the event is FREE to qualifying attendees. Secure your place now.

Attending Cloud & Infrastructure Live 2019 already? Why not enter the Computing Cloud Excellence Awards that will be celebrated in the evening, too?

The meetings were held by the members of Chinese National Development and Reform Commission and the Ministry of Commerce and Ministry of Industry and Information Technology. Executives from the world's major technology and semiconductor firms, including SK Hynix of South Korea and the semiconductor makers ARM of Britain were present in those meetings, the Times claimed, citing two people familiar with the matter.

The move follows a recent warning by Chinese officials that the country's government was setting up a blacklist of "unreliable entities" in retaliation for the US action against Huawei. The blacklist would be similar to the US 'Entity List' of companies that US companies must seek a licence before supplying.

Last month, the Trump administration announced its decision to include telecoms equipment maker Huawei on the US Entity List over national security concerns. The decision resulted in Huawei being cut off from the sales of US technology, on which it depends for key parts of its products, threatening the company's global ambitions.

The ban was later relaxed for a period of 90 days, giving US smartphone makers, internet service providers and other companies that do business with Huawei three more months to make alternative arrangements.

The New York Times notes that a permanent ban on Huawei (or other Chinese companies) could interfere with the long-term technology plans of China. Chinese officials have warned US companies against shifting their production lines from China to other countries - even as Chinese companies move production to Bangladesh and Vietnam - and have also asked them to raise their voices in opposition against the US government's recent policies.

Non-American firms have been told that they won't be punished by China's government if they continued to supply technology to Chinese firms.

Last week, Facebook announced its decision to cut off Huawei from its social networking app in order to comply with the US policies. Google made a similar decision last month.

Huawei argues that the allegations of trade theft and national security complaints are simply US excuses to prevent the Chinese company from becoming more powerful. It claims that it is part of a conspiracy to disrupt China's efforts to launch superfast, next-generation 5G technology in the coming months.

Computing and CRN have united to present the Women in Tech Festival UK 2019, on 17 September in London.

The event will celebrate successful women in the IT industry, enabling attendes to hear about, and to share, personal experiences of professional journeys and challenges.

Whether you're the 'Next Generation', an 'Inspirational Leader', or an 'Innovator of Tech' this event will offer inspiration on not only how to improve yourself, but how to help others too. The event is FREE for qualifying IT pros, but places will go fast

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T82-89G1-DY2R-201W-00000-00China will struggle to produce another Jack Ma;Alibaba2018-09-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisLEADERChina will struggle to produce another Jack MaAlibaba

No entrepreneur has defined China's transformation like Jack Ma. His success will be hard to repeat

THE most recognisable face of Chinese capitalism belongs to Jack Ma, the founder of Alibaba, an e-commerce juggernaut matched in size only by Amazon. Mr Ma, who launched Alibaba from a small apartment in Hangzhou in 1999, is an emblem of China's extraordinary economic transformation. This week's announcement that he will step down as the firm's chairman a year from now, to concentrate on philanthropy, was greeted with comparative calm by investors. He stopped being chief executive in 2013; Alibaba's share price has more than doubled since its initial public offering, the world's largest-ever, in 2014 (see "Corporate leadership in China: Command and control"). But one question presents itself: could China produce another story to match his? The answer is almost certainly not.

There are some very good reasons for that. China's own rise is an unrepeatable one. When Mr Ma, then an English-language teacher, launched Alibaba, the country was still gearing up to join the World Trade Organisation. Its GDP per head, in terms of purchasing-power parity, stood at under $3,000; it is now more than six times higher. The internet was still young, too. Less than 1% of Chinese had access to the web back then, compared with some 36% of Americans. As incomes grew and connections proliferated, Mr Ma took full advantage.

Thousands of small businesses have since flourished on Alibaba's platforms. About 1m merchants trade in its virtual emporiums. Its services have helped push China's economy towards consumption-led growth. Last year it boasted sales of $25bn on Singles' Day, China's equivalent of Black Friday (when Americans spent a measly $5bn). It has transformed logistics and finance, as well as retailing. Last year Alibaba delivered an average of 55m packages a day; its financial offshoot, Ant Financial, accounts for more than half of China's vast mobile-payments market. Its reach is so great that many startups decide to work with Alibaba rather than strike out alone.

But more has changed than the structure of China's economy and the clout of digital giants like Alibaba. Politics has changed, too. Alibaba thrived partly thanks to Mr Ma's skilful dealings with China's ruling Communist Party, with which he cultivated both closeness and stand-offishness ("Love them, don't marry them," he once said of the government). Under the leadership of President Xi Jinping, however, China's political system has grown hostile to private businesses that become too big or too disruptive. Officials have constrained bosses' freedom to make splashy deals. Bytedance, a brash technology firm set up in 2012, has been reined in, and forced to withdraw one of its apps. Its founder issued a grovelling public apology after being chastised by the government. Ant, meanwhile, has seen its aspirations to compete with state-owned banks held back by regulators (see "Ant and Tencent: And now for something completely different").

China is putting its corporate champions at the service of its ambitions to compete globally in high-tech industries. Alibaba's task is to use artificial intelligence to improve cities. Through state-backed venture-capital funds, the government is pouring money into industries that were once the preserve of the private sector. Rumours occasionally surface that it plans to take stakes and board seats in big tech firms. All this has fed growing international suspicion of China, especially in America. Mr Ma was one of the first out of the blocks to congratulate President Donald Trump on his election victory; this year America prevented Ant's purchase of MoneyGram, a money-transfer firm, on national-security grounds. The reality was always more complicated, but Mr Ma embodies an idea of China as market-driven and open. That idea has faded.

None of this is to say that enterprise is fizzling in China. Indeed one of Mr Ma's legacies is a shift to a culture that values startups more than ever. His charisma and folksy advice have earned him cult-like status among the country's entrepreneurs. Venture capitalists are lavishing money on hundreds of newcomers, in industries from biotech to electric vehicles. Small private firms will continue to flourish.

But it is harder to be as disruptive today as Mr Ma was 20 years ago. That is partly because his own creation is so dominant. Increasingly, however, the greatest obstacle to disruption is China's rulers. The party is intent on having a say much earlier in the development of industries that it considers important. As a result, China is unlikely to see new business leaders with the boldness and brio to match Mr Ma.

urn:contentItem:5XF3-J1R1-DXKX-01DV-00000-00Chinese App TikTok, Apple Both 'Refusing' to Testify, Says Sen. Hawley2019-11-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisChinese App TikTok, Apple Both 'Refusing' to Testify, Says Sen. Hawley

Nov 04, 2019( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) Two tech companies have allegedly declined to testify at a hearing held by Senator Josh Hawley (R-MO) about their dealings on China.The hearing, held by the Senate Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism[1], will focus on 'How Corporations and Big Tech Leave Our Data Exposed to Criminals, China, and Other Bad Actors.' Hawley tweeted[2], 'I've invited @Apple[3] and @tiktok_us[4] to testify on Tuesday about their business in with China and the risks to American consumers. So far, they are both refusing.

Something to hide?'TikTok 'said it was unable to send a suitable delegate 'on short notice' but was committed to 'working productively' with Congress,' reported the BBC.[5] On Nov. 1, a national security review[6] of TikTok and its owner, Beijing ByteDance, was reportedly launched, with a special interest in the company's $1 billion purchase of the U.S. social media app Musical.ly. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) claims that TikTok did not seek clearance, according to Reuters[7], when it purchased Musical.ly.TikTok uses similar censorship tactics[8] as those in its mother country, China. The company has banned political ads, videos dealing with Christianity, and LGBT material. More so, the app as it is used in China has promoted Chinese Communist Party propaganda[9], including a video displaying a Chinese torture device, a tiger chair.In an interview with Axios[10], Hawley slammed Silicon Valley tech companies, such as Apple and TikTok, for trading 'our basic democratic values and the privacy and security of Americans in order to make a buck in China and to get the favor of the Beijing government.'Apple has invested a large portion of marketing into China. CEO Tim Cook was recently appointed chairman[11] of the advisory board for Tsinghua University's economics school in Beijing. He serves along with several major Chinese government officials. The company recently removed an app[12] that was being used by protestors in Hong Kong to avoid police checkpoints.After the app was pulled, Cook[13] went out of his way to meet with Chinese regulators, where he discussed Apple's proposed expansion in China.These tech companies are not the only ones involved with China. Reddit[14] recently received a $150 million investment from Chinese company Tencent, which has also poured money into Blizzard/Activision[15], the gaming company responsible for World of Warcraft. urn:contentItem:5XF4-1S71-JCMN-Y32G-00000-00Chinese App TikTok, Apple Both 'Refusing' to Testify, Says Sen. Hawley2019-11-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:17ZLexisNexisChinese App TikTok, Apple Both 'Refusing' to Testify, Says Sen. HawleyCorinne Weaver

Nov 04, 2019( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) Two tech companies have allegedly declined to testify at a hearing held by Senator Josh Hawley (R-MO) about their dealings on China.The hearing, held by the Senate Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism[1], will focus on 'How Corporations and Big Tech Leave Our Data Exposed to Criminals, China, and Other Bad Actors.' Hawley tweeted[2], 'I've invited @Apple[3] and @tiktok_us[4] to testify on Tuesday about their business in ...th China and the risks to American consumers. So far, they are both refusing.

Something to hide?'TikTok 'said it was unable to send a suitable delegate 'on short notice' but was committed to 'working productively' with Congress,' reported the BBC.[5] On Nov. 1, a national security review[6] of TikTok and its owner, Beijing ByteDance, was reportedly launched, with a special interest in the company's $1 billion purchase of the U.S. social media app Musical.ly. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) claims that TikTok did not seek clearance, according to Reuters[7], when it purchased Musical.ly.TikTok uses similar censorship tactics[8] as those in its mother country, China. The company has banned political ads, videos dealing with Christianity, and LGBT material. More so, the app as it is used in China has promoted Chinese Communist Party propaganda[9], including a video displaying a Chinese torture device, a tiger chair.In an interview with Axios[10], Hawley slammed Silicon Valley tech companies, such as Apple and TikTok, for trading 'our basic democratic values and the privacy and security of Americans in order to make a buck in China and to get the favor of the Beijing government.'Apple has invested a large portion of marketing into China. CEO Tim Cook was recently appointed chairman[11] of the advisory board for Tsinghua University's economics school in Beijing. He serves along with several major Chinese government officials. The company recently removed an app[12] that was being used by protestors in Hong Kong to avoid police checkpoints.After the app was pulled, Cook[13] went out of his way to meet with Chinese regulators, where he discussed Apple's proposed expansion in China.These tech companies are not the only ones involved with China. Reddit[14] recently received a $150 million investment from Chinese company Tencent, which has also poured money into Blizzard/Activision[15], the gaming company responsible for World of Warcraft.
